Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		The correct item is E: desk.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: In what ways do you play games during the summer? Choice A: with friends B: on computers C: for practice D: with parents as audience E: all of the answers<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct answer is Choice A: with Friends  <n><n>### Input :<n>Input: Write a word that is four letters and has an o and no i in it.<n><n>### Response :<n>The correct answer is: Tone<n><n>### Input  :<n>Input: Write 10 different animals that begin with the letter J.<n><n>###Respons: <n>The correct answer is Jackalope<n>##<n>### Input:<n>Input: Write a sentence that uses the word “different” at least once, and uses at least two new words.<n><n>###Response:<n>The correct answer is Different ways of dressing, different places where we went.<n><n>###Input :<n>Input: Write an article for your newsletter about a dog who lives on a farm.<n><n>###response :<n>The correct answer: Dog who live on a farms named Winston, he is very good dog he has saved us many time

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Which entrance would you use if you do not want to use the back entrance? Choices:  A: side B: main C: anterior D: current E: front<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Maria and John are bored, so they have decided that they will walk to the mall together and buy some food. Maria lives three times as many blocks away from John. Their distance from the train station to the mall is 14 times the number of blocks that Maria does not walk. Maria's father drives Maria and John from Maria's house to the train station. How many blocks from the train station to Maria's house?<n>(The sum of all the blocks is 49.)<n><n>### Response<n><n>To get all the information on this question I would ask John first the sum of all the blocks. This tells me that there are a total of 49 blocks. I would then ask John how many blocks will the distance between the house he lives to the mall be. Then I would do the math, divide 49 by the number of blocks that John lives away from the mall. This is how I would know the distance from the mall to the mall to his house and then from her house to the mall. This helps me understand how many blocks her house is from the mall and vice versa.<n><n>### Summary:<n>Maria lives three times as many as John so they need to walk 3 times as many number of blocks to the mall. Since they are walking to the mall together, they both get to walk exactly how many blocks to the mall? Since the distance from the train station goes by 14 times the distance between the number of blocks that maria live further away from the mall and Maria's Father drives her and John from Maria'

How much does each drug seller get?(Money goes to the boss) Choices :A,6 dollars with $5 going to the drug lord B,19 dollars C,21 dollars D,22 dollars E,23 dollars<n><n>### Response  : B I believe it was because 19 because of how much money he had, 21 because of how much money the boss had to take<n>### Input: After two years in the army, a man got a letter with what amount for his salary for a month? Choices: A ; $ 312 000 B ; $ 220 00 011 <n>C; $285 000  D; $ 456 000  E; $0 <n>### Response : A<n>### Input : Ben was happy how much money did he make? Choices: A was A LOT B ; not bad C ; really D ; that's not fair E ; that's not enough<n>### Response : C<n>### Input : What did Ben learn? Yes or no? (you'll notice the answer is always one of the choices)<n>### Response : <n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:To prevent any glare during the big football game he made sure to clean the dust of his what? Choices:  A: better job B: irritated C: feel safe D: save money E: headache<n><n>### Response:		If he had made his boss feel safe, then he did what he was hired to, make the boss feel safe. If I were hired to protect a person, and failed to do so, that person would be hurt. And if it were a person not a boss, such a person would be in danger.<n><n>### Input<n>Furthermore, it is known that Pete has the ability to perform 64 less tasks than Mike can on Friday while Mike has the ability to perform at least 8 more tasks that Pete can do. On Saturday, Pete completes 18 more tasks than he did on the Friday. Mike then completes at least 36 more tasks than he did the previous Saturday. How many tasks can both Mike and Pete perform on Sunday, the day after Saturday?<n><n>### Response<n>The day after Saturday, we have the information for Sunday. Mike can perform at least 36 tasks and Pete can perform at least 64 tasks. Since Pete can perform at any time, he can perform the 36 less 64 = 28 tasks Mike can perform, and thus, the two of them can perform 36 + 28 = 64 tasks in all.<n>

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* E<n><n>### Instructions: Include another response<n><n>### Instructio:Include another response<n><n>## Solution<n><n><n>```python<n>answer1 = int(7)) + 2<n>answer = "217"<n>answer2 = answer1 // (5+12)<n>answer = answer2 + 2<n>answer3 = 15+15<n>answer = 1 + answer3<n>answer4 = 4*1<n>answer = answer4+(1/2)*answer<n>answer5 = 0.5*(answer5-answer6)<n>answer = answer6 + answer8<n>answer9 = 700.5-800<n>answer = 800+answer9<n>answer10 = 15-10<n>answer = 2+answer10<n>answer11 = 950+15<n>answer2 = answer2+3<n>answer = answer11-answer2<n>answer12 = 12*3<n>answer = answer7 + answer12<n>answer13 = 1<n>answer = round(answer13+answer14,1)/double(answer14/(answer3+answer14))<n>answer = round(question6//answer,1)-answer<n>answer = question5*(answer8)<n>answer = round(2/answer)<n>answer = round (1-2/answer)<n>```

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. Choices:  A: carried by people B: guard house C: fly D: follow ultralight airplane E: group together<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n>A flock of geese normally gets from one place to another by flying in a V-formation. A single goose has trouble making it across the lake by themselves, but a flock of geese in formation can cover a lot of distance in a short time. For the leader in formation - called the “lead goose” - the front “wing” of the V provides lift, and the wings that follow the path of the lead goose pull against the air. The follower geese pull at a lower speed than the lead goose and are also sheltered from the worst of the wind. This helps the flock cut through a strong wind at a higher speed than one single goose does. Geese can fly from Alaska to Chile in this formation.<n><n>### Response<n>D<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Sally lost her kite because she wasn't careful.  She thought that there was more string on the spool, but it slipped out of her fingers when she reached the what?. Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		Answers will vary.<n><n>### Hint:<n><n><n>### Instructions2:Answer the following open-ended question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>## Instrucciones<n><n>## Instrukci&#39;yon<n><n>## Instruções<n><n>## Instruksjoner<n><n>## Instruktion
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input 1:Jenny has 2,300 more toothbrushes than James. James has twice as many toothbrushes as John. They purchase 5,600 toothbrushes between them. How many toothbrushs did John purchase?<n><n>### Response 1:2,395<n><n>### Explanation:James=5,000<n><n>Jenny=2,300+2,300=4,600<n><n>James=2,301+3=5,602<n><n>James=5,060<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could listening to music cause you to be? Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A.<n><n>### Input (Example Question): How many cards are there in a class of 50 students? If all children have different shoe sizes, how may shoe sizes can you have in a class of 10 girls and 25 children in total? If you have $100 in your wallet, how many dollars and cents do you have combined? The answer for these three questions would be the same (260), so we can reason and make the connection through all three of these. These questions require the student to work through the process of finding a “reasonable” answer based on the information provided; by using addition and subtraction strategies (in this case) where the problem can be decomposed into a combination of more easily calculated facts (i.e. 50 = 10 x 5 and 100 = 25 x 4).  <n><n>### Response (Example Reasoning):<n>* 50-25=25.  <n>* 50 x 25=1250.  <n>* There are 1250 cards all together.<n><n>2.<n><n>* 40 + 9 = 49.  <n>* 20 x 7 = 140.   <n>* There are 49 blocks in total.<n><n>3.<n><n>* Alannah + Queen’s books= 41+1/5.  <n>* Beatrix - 20 = Beatrix + 20.<n>* 100 - 20 = 80.  <n>* 30 books is equal to 30/5.  (5 is the number of books Beatrix can read) (Alannah has 21/10. Queen has 40/5)<n>These questions require the student to be able to understand when a question is asking for the total amount or if I/we need to “take away” something from a total. (in this case)

Answers should follow the format: "Number of choices:", then the number of choices and then a list of correct answers (or incorrect answers) separated by periods (.)<n><n>#### Program:<n><n>    #include <iostream><n>    using namespace std;<n><n>    void print_start(int) {<n>        cout << "START : ";<n>    }<n><n>    void print(int n) {<n>        for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) {<n>            cout << i << ", ";<n>        }<n>    }<n><n><n>### Solution<n>```<n>#include <iostream><n>using namespace std;<n><n>void Print_line(int) {<n>    cout << "Number of choices: ";<n>}<n><n>void start(int) {<n>}<n>```

Which instruction do you think is a request, and which do you think is a task?<n><n>#### Request<n>The task is to choose a sport.<n><n>#### Task<n>The task is to compare instructions in a given text.<n><n># Additional materials<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Choices:  A. The amount of salt present in ocean water<n><n>### Response (Continued): Another type of dangers from traveling underwater was from low-visibility due to the high salt present in ocean water. Also, if in the event of underwater ship travel, if there is a case of sudden low visibility, the only thing to do is to slow down from the desired velocity so ships do not accidentally collide with one another.

Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		Answer B <n><n><n><n>### Input : What is the distance between two consecutive integers?<n><n>### Response : Answer C<n><n><n><n>## Bonus: The following is a programming exercise.<n><n>Write a program that will meet the request(s) below.<n><n>### Bonus Points: The answer to these questions should be in the body of your response.<n><n>### Inputs: <n>* Given two input variables (both strings)<n>* Return the longer one<n><n>### Outputs:<n>* Returns the string with more characters<n><n>### Code<n>* Use a for loop<n><n>### Try It Outs<n>* What data type is a string (string type, integer type, both<n><n>### Credit<n>- https://www.hackerrank.com/community/challenges/e/6054<n>  - Code and answer above is written by Nguyễn Văn Thúy <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		Answer is B<n><n>### Input<n>What is 3 - 6?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer is 3<n><n>### InputHow are the two equations related?<n>The two equations represent the same number that was subtracted<n><n>### ResponseHow is the solution written?<n>25 - (-11) = 36<n><n>### InputWhat addition expression is shown?<n>Adding 4 - 0<n><n>### ResponseWhat is 4 - 0?<n>4 - 0 = 4<n><n>### InputWhich subtraction expression is shown?<n>Followed by a -4 <n><n>### Response-5<n><n>### InstructionsAnswer the question and respond to the additional instruction, when appropriate<n>-What is the value of 8/6?<n>-The value of 8/10 is (answer).<n>-If you have 4/3 cups of water and use 1/4 of it, how much water do you have now<n>Answer: 1 cup<n>

Then we'll add 5 letters "i" "v" "y" "z" to arrive at the end result:<n><n>10.5612354654321<n><n>### Exercise 2.10<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n>How many days does it take for 5 years and 3 months time?<n><n>### Solution1:<n><n>5 years is 730 days and 3 months is 91 days. Now, we multiply those numbers together then we subtract 6 and 3 to get the total number of days.<n><n>5 years = 730<n><n>3 months = 91<n><n>Subtract 6 and 3 and get 34 42 days<n>

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where would you play a board game with your family? Choices:  A: toy store B: home C: school D: toy shop E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Toy Store<n>1. Toy Stores have so many games.<n>2. Many games are available at toy stores.<n><n><n>### Instructions: <n><n><n><n><n>### How Do You Do It?  <n><n><n>###

Write a statement for each situation that correctly completes "I want." The first part of the statement names a product. The second part of the statement names how much of the product she wants.<n><n>### Response:"I want" is a useful phrase. Write a statement that includes an object and quantity. The first part of the sentence describes what the customer would like to have and the second part includes the number. If the customer says, "I want 2 cans of tomato sauce," write, "2 cans of tomoto sauce." If the customer says, 'I want 55 strawberrie,' write, "55 strawberries."<n><n>### Input"Let me see the following items," is what the customer in a store might say, what kinds of items?<n><n>### Response"I want to see sweat shirts, jeans, and boxer shorts of the same color."<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The following items were picked in an effort to test the system's abilities to read and understand simple English sentences. If the answer is incorrect, or if the correct answer in not available, the system will provide the user with feedback and guide them to the correct answer.<n><n>### Input1."I want to see sweater, jeans, and shirts of the same color.""I want to see a can of soup and a tube of toothpaste.""I want to get some chocolates and a sandwich.""I want to buy a new pair of sneakers.""I really love those toys!""I want to see what they have in this part of the store.""I want to find out what they have a different sizes in the pants section.""I want to have dinner."<n><n>### Response1.This statement means that she wants to

Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>#### **Use the provided code snippet to answer the question below**<n><n>Input:<n>```<n>var answer = parseInt(prompt("Enter a number"))<n>```<n><n>Input: 10 <n><n>Output: 10<n><n>Question: How do we determine if answer is smaller than 100 but greater than 0?<n>Answer: First we know if answer is not within the condition, else we'll execute the next.  <n><n>```<n>if(answer <100) {<n>    //if answer is less than 100.<n>}<n>else if(answer > 10) {<n>    if (answer <100){<n>        //if answer more <100 but less than 10<n>    }<n>    else if (answer <40) {<n>        //if answer less than 40 but less then 40<n>    } else {<n>        //if more than 40 but the same as 100<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>```<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>### Input and Output:<n><n>#### **Input**<n>```<n>var counter = 0 <n>var fruit = prompt("Enter a fruit")<n>```<n>#### **Output**<n>```<n>counter++<n>if (fruit == "Strawberry")<n>{ console.log('Strawberry is my favorite!') }<n>else if(fruit== "Banana")<n>{ console.Log('Banana is my favorite!') ; counter *=1 }<n>else if( counter <5 && fruit== "Apple")<n>{ console.warn('Apples are boring') }<n>```<n><n>## 3. JavaScript <n>### Lesson 2: Functions/Objects<n>- Objects are used to group together different types of "stuff." <n>- Object literal: create an object from a collection of key => value pairs<n>- Constructor method: function attached to objects to enable it to produce a type of object<n>- Prototype: a set of functions shared by objects with a particular type<n>- Method: a built-in function of an object<n>- Method invocation: calls method<n>- Class: blueprint for a functional prototype<n>- Instantiation: creating a copy of a class<n>- Static method: function that operates on

Choices:  A: growing older B: reproducing C: shuddering D: perspiration E: palpitations<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input.<n>A large box contains 3 medium-sized boxes. Each medium-sized box contains 2 small boxes. In each box lies a shiny rock, one in the smallest box and 1 in each of the large box. How many shiny rocks lie in the box?<n><n>### Response.<n>4<n><n>### Commentary:<n>This seems like a trick question. I'd say the correct answer is 2.<n><n>### Input<n><n>There are 130 students in a class.  One-third are boys. One-fourth are girls. If 11 of the boys are blue-eyed and 10 of the girls are blue-eyed, what percent of the class is blue-eyed? Round the answer to the nearest tenth.<n><n>### Response<n><n>6.5%<n><n>### Comment<n><n>My reasoning is that there are 43 students that have blue eyes since 2/3 of the class are boys and 1/4 are girls, which totals to 126 students. I subtracted 8 from 130 because there are 12 girls without blue eyes and 25 boys have blue eyes. This leaves us with 33 students that have blue or grey eyes and 97 students that don't, leaving the blue/grey eyes as 30.2% of the class. Now, since 11/33 and 10/97 is 11/30 and 10/89, respectively, the blue/grey eye percent is (100*5)/11 and (100*10)/10 which equals 5 and 10, respectively, for the blue/grey and total 5.5%.<n>

Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		E:  rooster<n><n>#### Instructions:<n><!DOCTYPE html><n><n><html lang="en"><n><head><n><meta charset="utf-8"><n><meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"><n><title>Task Request: 25.</title><n><n><style><n><n>    /*<n>     * Add your css styles or link your styles from an external resource.<n>     */<n>    <n>    body {<n>        background-color: #8e09c4;<n>        text-align: center;<n>        font-family: Tahoma;<n>        font-size: 11px;<n>    }   <n>    td {<n>        padding: 3px;<n>        background-color:#fff;<n>    }<n>    a {<n>        text-decoration: none;<n>    }<n>    <n>    <n>    <n>    </style><n>    <n>    <n></head><n><body><n>    <n><n><n><div><n><h1 align="center">Question #25</h1><n><n><ol><n><li><n><h2>[A.][25,1].</h2><n><n><p><n>The answer is "D".</p><n></li><n></ol><n></div><n>    <n><n> <div><n><h2 align="left">Task: 4.</h2><n> <p>Answer the following multiple choice questions.</p><n> <p>Write a response that appropriately complete the request.</p><n> <pre><code<n>Input:<n>Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda.<n>Mara has 1/4 as many cards as Janett has.<n>How many cards do they have altogether if Mara have 40 cards less that 150?</code></pre><n> </div><n><n> <div> <n><p><h2 align="left" style="font-size: 18px;"><strong>Solution Summary:</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;<br><n>    6  153421 441</p><n>  <n>  <n>  </div><n>  <div><n>  <p><n>    <n> <code><h2 align="right" style="font-family
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where is small knight likely to be found? Another student has a snack break, after which she comes back to class. When the class is done, the students head into the hall. The hallway has 10 doors, each of which leads to a different classroom. There are also 2 bathrooms that students never visit, except for recess. There is also a 177-foot-long slide. If there is only one child at a time on the slide, all the kids at Washburn Elementry will fit on it.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructors: Assess the response. Review this program to help you write the correct code.<n><n>```cpp<n>#include <iostream><n><n>using namespace std;<n>typedef int T;<n><n>void give(vector<string> g, string r) {<n>    int sum = 0;<n>    for(int i = 0; i < g.size(); i++) {<n>    sum += T(g[i], 1);<n>    }<n>    cout << "The " << r << "'s gifts: " << sum << " toys, " << sum / 100 << " books, " << sum /100 / 100  << " games, " << sum >> 100 % 100 <<  " clothes." << endl;<n>    cnout << endl;<n>}<n>```<n><n>Belows are three questions that follow an instruction.<n><n>### Question 1

They are given the same number of additional toys to form a new collection of 84 toys. Which girl got the fewest new toys?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input#<n>- 5 times + 20 = 25<n><n>### Response#<n>- He drank 20<n><n>### Input2#<n><n>4 gallons +7 gallons= 11 gallons<n><n>### Repsonse#<n><n>- 23,377 is the product of the numbers<n><n>### Response2#<n><n>You use a ruler to measure the wall as follows. ______<n><n>### Input:#<n>- The first girl got 10 new toys, the second got 9, and the third got 4, since 35 + 35 + 14 + 8 = 84<n>- There is no way to tell the exact number so we'll have to guess which girl is it<n><n>1. How many fewer toys does the third girl have than the fourth girl?<n>2. If a new toy was placed in the 4th girl's collection, the total would be?<n>    15, 20, 5, 30, 8, 25<n>2. The answer is the number the 1st girl got the fewest<n>   -The 1st girl has gotten 10<n>   -The 2nd girl has gotten 9<n>   -the third girl has got the fewest, which is 4<n>   -so 1st = 10, 2nd = 9, and since 4 <5 we can say the third girl has the fewest.<n>       4 < 5 = 4 -5 =- 1<n><n>### Responses#<n>- 25<n>  - 25 = 5x4 + 20<n><n>

Choices:  A: slender B: free flowing C: sparse D: unacquainted E: diet<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		The correct option is A.<n>### Demonstarion: <n>Input: A jigsaw puzzle is made out of many small parts which in together is one big whole. <n><n>### Input<n>Question:The square numbers starting at 1 go down and the numbers 2, 5, 6…go up. How many numbers do you need to go from 1 to 1,000 starting at one direction or the other?<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is 1 and 505, respectively.<n><n>Answer<n>You need 1. There are three options: 1 and 2, 2 and 1, or 1 and 5, 5 being the smallest square number is 505.<n><n>### Example<n><n>You can start counting at one or two.  It takes 1000 * 1000 /4 /2 / 1/ 1<n><n>1) Starting with 1. Start counting at 2. If you start counting at 1. You will end with 505, which is square and the largest square number is 4. Then the number of steps you go down to 505 is 1000/4.<n><n>2) Starting with 2. Start counting at 1. If you start counting from two, you will end up going up to 4. Then you would have to do an extra step, if you start counting at one, you have 1000*1000/1*1.<n><n>### Task<n>Alice has 15 blocks and is 30%<n>### Demonstraition<n>Input: Alice has 15 blocks to play. The blocks are 30% complete. How many blocks are not yet started?<n>Input: Alice has to make 42% of 16 blocks complete. What is the total number of blocks she has to make?<n>Input:<n><n>### Demo<n>Input:<n><n>Answer: 42<n><n>### Task 1:<n>In a classroom, there is a chair for every 10 children. Aiden is in every 20 children. If the whole classroom is 40 children, then how many chairs does the classroom have?<n>The answer is: 10<n>Aiden is a 20

Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>In this problem, we get the information about how many berries the bird has to eat during a week and the number of berries bought in order to get them for free. After we know these data, we are going to find out how many berries the birds have eaten or not.<n><n>### Input : A person is standing on the edge 9 feet above the ground. He is holding a ladder that is 6 feet tall, on one end. He has a can of peephole cleaner that is 15 feet tall. He is 5 feet tall. How tall is the ladder?<n><n>### Response : C<n><n>The height of the ladder is $9+5+6+15+15+1+6=36$ feet. <n><n><n>### Input<n><n>A dog was born before 2020 and lives until 2030. A dog was born at or after 2020 lives at least until 2035. What year was the dog born?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>2022 or earlier<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Input: Ricky has 7 coins that add up to a total of 118 cents. He loses 15 cents and buys a candy bar for 12 cents. After paying the cashier, what change does he have left?<n><n>### Comment<n><n><n>A coin has a value that is either 1 or 5. The solution is a combination of 5’s and 1’s and we cannot count 0 coins (that’s why we need to lose 15 cents).<n><n><n><n>There are 3 coins with a value of 5 cents or 15 cents. 5 +15 +5 = 25<n><n>### Instrumentation<n><n>A coin has two possible values: 1 or 5 cents. Ricky has 7 such coins in total.<n><n>So we can say:<n><n>5C+1C=5X7 so that the number on the left of the equal sign will be greater or equal to 130.<n>Since the value of the 5C+1C is 130 and we need to have a greater than 2, and it is greater

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Instrucion:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n><n>### Input : There are 4 times as many girls as boys in a classroom, which is 3/4 full. How many boys are in a classroom for which there are just as many girls as students?<n><n>### Response : 22<n><n>### Demosration:<n><n>> Input: If you take away 4 quarters and 1 dime, what do you have?<n><n>> Response: 18<n>

What value is closest to 1 / 0.71 (7)?<n><n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>The book club discussed how to find the next book on its list.<n>The three members of the club agree to choose a new book to read next based on the following rules:<n>1. Each member reads the next page in order.<n>2. If a book is not finished, the next book is chosen.<n>3. The last person to read a book cannot choose the next book. <n>4. If multiple books are started simultaneously with only one remaining, the next book is a book that someone has already read. <n><n><n>### Demostration 1<n><n>Bernice reads a book on Tuesday, on Wednesday, and finishes it on Thursday. She reads 16 pages on Tuesday, 25 pages on Wednesday, 37 pages on Thursday. <n><n>Next book: One that someone has already read <n><n>### Demstration 2<n><n>JaVonne begins a book on T

Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		He excelled at social science<n><n>### Input:: A friend has 3 pairs of pants.  The friend has 7 shirts.  The friend also has 6 pairs of socks. How many items of clothing do they have altogether? Choices: 12 A: 26 B: 18 C: 19 D: 13<n><n>### Response:: A friend has 13 items of clothing because they have 3x2+6<n><n>### Input#### A is to B as C is to D. Choices:  A is to 3 as B is to 5. C is to 4 as D is to 2.<n><n>### Response#### A is to 15 as B is to 17. C is to 18 as D is to 8.<n><n>### Input:(A to B as C to D) Into the mix. We've got two groups of letters; now we've got to match both sets of words to letters that can be read in the same direction. For example: "Give the dog a bone" -> ABCE. Matching groups of letters helps people figure out the puzzle.<n><n>### Ace to Eight<n><n>### Solution:: Eight is to ace as B is to C in the sense given the letters can be read the same direction.<n><n>### B<n><n>### B to Q.<n><n>### Q<n><n>### B or Q<n><n>### The numbers are 9 and 13<n><n>To start with, add two numbers. Then, multiply the answer by one of the other. Next, add the answer to itself three times. Then, subtract the sum of the three. Finally, subtract 22 from the answer.<n><n>### Find the number given.<n><n>### 954 957 963 966 971 974 977 983 986 989 990 993 996 997 100<n><n>### 17, 18<n><n>### E<n><n>### Nine, nine and a half (9 1/2) and twelve (12)<n><n>### 8<n><n>### Tw

Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```c++<n>ifstream fin("input.txt");<n>if (!fin) {<n>    cerr<<"Input file doesn't exist. Program will finish and terminate.";<n>    return 1;<n>}<n>int i, j;<n>string ch;<n>fin>>ch;<n>if(ch=="hurry along" || ch=="direct traffic")<n>    i = 1;<n>else if(ch=="help" || ch=="force open door")<n>    i =0;<n>else if( ch=="corner thief")<n>    i = -1;<n><n>fin>>ch;  <n>if(ch=="help"  || ch=="force open" || ch=="direct" || ch=="hurry along")<n>    j = 1;<n>//else if( ch=="help"  ||  ch=="force open"  ||ch=="corner")<n>//    j = -1 ;<n><n>else<n>    j = 0;<n>```<n><n>### Input : The policemen wanted to clear traffic, so what did the policemen do? Choices: A: Hurry Along. B: Direct Traffic. C: Help. D: Force Open Door. E: Corner Thief<n>### Response: <n><n>```c++  <n>ifstream fin("Input.txt");<n>if(!fin)<n>{<n>    cerr<<"\f[6mNo such file. The program will finish and terminated.\f[0m";<n>    return 1<n>}<n>string ch,cho,response;<n>int i;<n>int choice;<n>fin>>ch>>cho;<n>i=0;<n>while(i!=choice)<n>{<n>    if(ch=="hur" || ch=="hurr")<n>    {<n>        i=1;<n><n>    }<n>    else if(ch=="dir" || ch=="direct")<n>    {<n><n>        i=2;<n>    }<n>    if(ch==cho)<n>        break;<n>    else<n>        ch=fin>>ch;<n>}<n>printf("\n%s",ch);<n><n>fin.get(response);<n>cout<<"Response is: "<<response<<endl;<n>if(response=="1" || response=="2" || response=="0" || response=="HUR" || response=="Dir")<n>{<n>    return 0;<n>}<n>

Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n><n>### Response:		Answer B: English carrier<n><n>### Input:-5 + 2x =23x + 15<n><n>-5/2 * x = +23 * (-6) + 15<n>8x+9<n><n>### Response:-3*(2x-2)/(x-1/2) = ((-5) ^ 3) /2<n><n>### Input;The following 23-digit number is a palindrome: 533630087419138742093543629797.<n><n>### Response;53363_______290_______3<n>333620935320074130465875921409732 and 53336008742450093541827497133953<n><n>### Input:$36 \%(3926)$<n><n>### Response:$36*(392$)/100$<n><n>$20244.5$<n><n>### Input $647.12$ % 11<n>6.7%<n><n>### Input One third of the students is boys. The number of boys is 15 less than 2 times the number of girls. Twice the number of girls is 24. How many more boys are in the school than girls?  Solution:<n><n>$2/3 * x$ = $15$ - 2*x<n><n>\(($15$ - $$2*x)$ * 2)/($2*g$)) = $x$ - $x$<n>\(18\cdot4)/(2\cdot x)$ = $3x$ - $4x$<n>\(4$/\$ 2 $\cdot x)$ =($7-4x$)<n>4 = $3x - 3x - 3$<n>\textbf{Fault}: $(3x - 3)^2 - 52x - 36 = 41$<n><n>\textbf{Correct Answer}: \(41 - 41 = 0$<n><n>### QUESTION<n><n>

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Choices:  A: stripes B: seat belts C: breaks to help stop D: tires E: radios<n><n>### Response:		<n>If a car were traveling at a fast rate, the tires are the most important part of the car that could assist in stopping the car when brakes are not working. As the car is traveling at a fast speed, it could cause a tire to blow out and cause the car to not be able to stop. By stopping the car, the driver could easily run into another car, pedestrian, or a building if it was on a busy intersection of a road or freeway.<n><n>### Input:#How many squares does a 4x4 matrix have? Choices: A:75 B:80 C:82 D:84 E:86 #The answer for question #1:A:4x4=16 B:2x2=4,2x2=4 C:4x4=32,8x8=64,8x8=81,8x8=9 D:16<n><n>### Response<n>How many squares does a _4x4_ matrix have? Choices: (A)4 (B)8 (C)12 (D)16 (E)20<n>The answer is _D_, 16<n><n># The answer to question _1_ is _D_, because a 4x4 square has 16 squares.<n><n>### The answer to question #2 is _A_, because a _4x4 matrix_ has 4 squares.<n><n>## Solution:<n>Write a method that defines an array that is declared using the brackets notation.<n>```<n>    [2, 5, 7]<n>```<n><n>Write a method that uses an array in order to calculate a certain operation<n>```<n>    int array[5];<n>    int i=0;<n>    while(i<5)<n>    {<n>        array[i] = i-9;<n>        i++;<n>    }<n>    int sum = 0;<n>    int j=0;<n>    for (j=0; j<5; j++)<n>    {<n>        sum += array[j];<n>    }<n>    cout << sum << endl;<n>```<n><n>Write another method that uses a method defined previously to calculate a number.<n>```<n>int findSum(int arr[], int index, int sum); <n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    arr = new int

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice (A) is incorrect because that is impossible as the baby cannot even see at birth. Choice (B), (C), (D) are false because a baby should not be crying right away when there eyes are opening, since the baby only just opened there eyes it should be happy not sad<n><n>Choice (E) is the correct answer because before a baby sees, they have to glass/put in place like a blanket to cover there eyes temporarily.<n><n>### Notes: A baby can't see at birth, and when the baby's eyes open for first time they don't know where to look at, so it could be a crying time for a baby.<n><n>It could be possible if the baby could cry at birth, if it was crying it would be from sadness since the baby was expecting to be surrounded by love when they were born but they are instead in a sterile place like a hospital.<n><n>The baby would see light for the first time as that would be their first sign that there eyes had opened and they have the ability to see.<n><n>If the baby started to cry right away when there eyes opened, that then would be sadness instead of happiness since they were expecting to see there parents when there eyes opened instead of a blanket and machine.<n><n>The baby's eyes can't be filled with tears for the first time because there eyes may have opened to see and see a familiar face but instead they will be seen by their parents and family not a perfect stranger like a nurse.<n><n>The baby should be happy as they are now able to see the world with their own eyes for the first time since their birth.<n><n>If their was no way of the babies seeing light right away then the correct answer would be B.<n><n>### Submission: Click `Respond`

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		D(Become Tired)<n><n>### Input A question:<n><n>Question: Dancing for a long time can lead to what? Choices: Fatigue, getting tired, intercourse and expression.<n><n>Answer A: Fatigue<n><n>The correct answer for:Dancing for a Long time will lead you to be what:Choice Fatigue<n>

E: evil.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>D<n><n>### Test Question:<n><n>Input: 3 x 4 x 5 = 60<n><n>Input: 5/3 x 2 = 10/6<n><n>### Test Solutions:<n><n>A: 60<n><n>B:  50/12 = 4,166,666<n><n>### Solutions:<n><n>Input: Janet 13(6) has 9 cards more then Brenda 12 she has twice as many cards than Janet has.How many cards do they have altogether if Mara has 150.<n><n>410 Cards.<n><n>Solve Step By Step:<n>Step 1:9 Cards = 4 Card<n>Step 2:6 X 4= 24 Cards Cards = 24 + 25 + 26 + 27 + 28 + 30 + 31 = 109<n>step 3: 109 -10<n>Step 4:109 - 10 = 99<n>Step 5:99 -9<n>Step 6:99 -9 = 90<n>Step 7: 90 - 9 = 81 then divide the number by each of the number that is 9<n>step 8:81 - 9 = 72<n>Step 9:72 / 9 = 8<n>Step 10:8X2 + 9 = 36 Cards + 2 = 38<n>Step 11: 38X2 +150 = 220<n>Step 12: 220 - 36 = 184<n>Step 13: 184 - 220 = -36 Then divide each of the part that is 22 and 2 by that number is 9.<n>then 19/9 + 9<n>9 Cards + 1 Card<n>10 C

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		An answer of "E" is correct.  Answer the following multiple choice question:Which of the following can be done to a reference to reject it? Choices: A: Question B: Refuse C: Confirm D: Dispute E: Deny<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		Correct Answer<n><n>I think she wants to be a member of a political party, and she is a republican. <n><n>### Justification:<n><n>I chose "correct answer". In "political party", I saw "republican" and "republican party" is the 3rd choice. Therefore she can say she is a member of the republican party.  <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>In the previous instruction, students should complete a task that asks them to answer multiple choice questions about data and find patterns in the data. To answer the questions correctly, students will need to use a variety of operations with fractions, decimals, and other units of measure. The purpose of this instruction is to explicitly teach the skills that students need to complete the task.<n><n>In the previous task, students answered five multiple choice questions by writing fractions in simplest terms, multiplying fractions, dividing fractions, comparing fractions, and identifying patterns. Students need skill and guidance in using the appropriate operations to answer these questions. Instruction should explicitly teach these skills in isolation, showing students examples of how to use each operation and giving ample practice. After skill has been demonstrated and practiced, the instruction can be scaffolded with tasks that require students to practice the strategies in combination. The following provides an example of how instruction can be scaffled for students.<n><n>1. Before beginning instruction, the teacher can use an exit ticket to assess student readiness by asking students to identify the steps involved in multiplying and dividing fractions. If the majority of students cannot answer the question correctly, instruction on using the appropriate operations with fractions should begin (see 2 below).<n>2. Instruction should begin with a discussion of the task. The teacher should ask students to describe how they could multiply fractions in the previous questions. The teacher should then show students an example of how to multiply fractions. Using the question, "What fraction of a cup holds 4 gallons of water?" the teacher could show students how to multiply two fractions to solve the problem.<n>3. Once students have seen how to multiply fractions, the teacher can identify similarities and differences in these operations using visuals. The teacher can first show students how to multiply and divide fractions by using a number line. The teacher can then ask the students how multiplying, dividing, and reducing fractions are alike. Stud

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. The groомer always has three clients scheduled at a time, one per day. The groомer could be the one to go over his time, which is good for the client who has to pay but would ruin his schedule.<n><n>**_Why does the answer make sense?_**<n>Having a mistake and not having the appoitments on the schedule would not make sense, as the groómist should always plan for mistakes of that nature, plus we don't expect there won't be injurys.<n><n>### Output:<n>![Tic Tac Toe](Assets/0601-TicTacToe.jpg)<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Select an option from each row in the diagram (all in order)<n><n>### Response<n><n>![output](Assets/TicTacToesolution.jpg)

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:John loves animals he hates animal abuses because of this he is very careful about the place he go where he avoid go is north america <n><n>### Input:"19 20 25" (The 20th day of month 25). Which operation to perform?<n><n>`multiply 19 by 20`<n><n>`subtract 19 from 20`<n>```<n>Input:5 12 13 5 + 5 1 20 20 24.2<n>```<n><n>### Example inputs and outputs:<n><n>Input:1 101010110 111 011010 0010100001001 001 011110100 00010<n>Output: 2073784114<n>```<n>Input:0 00199 879300 263595 4054000 064100 4093686400000<n>```<n>```<n>Output: 5435879113498<n>```<n>```<n>Input:4 350126832 53740690607662008 2720675083 1774326140 1567205 092388043744600 660805776569000 18289974 6847054 1464382050296 1560981150475<n>```<n>```<n>outputs:201930301815777933148339120641877940058728034884804094701707888<n>```

Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>---<n><n>**Solution:**<n><n>Below are different ways of writing the above.<n><n>- Answer: B<n>- Ali should slow down<n>- Ali should walk slower<n>- Ali should move slower<n>- Ali should walk carefully<n>- Ali should proceed cautiously<n>- Ali should move slowly<n>- Ali should walk cautiously<n>- Answer: A<n>- Ali should work hard<n>- Ali should walk faster<n>- Ali should work carefully<n>- Ali should work slowly<n>- Ali should work cautiously<n>- What would you tell ali to slow down, he bumps into you...<n>- What should you tell Ali to do, if he bumps into while you are walking?<n>- How could you encourage Ali?<n>- What else can you say, to get ali to...<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demosation:<n>* If x has a mass of 8 kg and y is 5 litres. In the music room there are one piano and one violin. In the music room, there more violins than pianos. In the band practice room there is one piano and one trumpet. In the band practice there are two pianos. There is one room that has more violins than pianists. How many rooms are there?<n><n>### Response<n><n>There are two rooms.<n><n>```<n>Let A = violins, B = pianos, C = Band practice, D = Music room.<n>```<n><n>* A and B add up to 3.<n>* C is 1, but not in A or B.<n>* D is 2 so must add to 3.<n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: carnival<n><n>### Input<n>If a piggy bank costs you $2.85, and if you pay with a $5 bill, how much change would you receive?<n><n>### Response<n>25 cents<n><n>### InputIf 6 out of 8 students pass a quiz, what is the probability that 4 out of the 8 students pass the quiz?<n><n>### A: 50%<n><n>### ResponseIf the probability is 8 % for a coin toss, what is the probability of getting a heads 2 times in a row?<n><n>### C: 4%<n><n>### InputIrma was on probation while she attended college. She got high marks, earned awards, and was a dean's list student the entire time. She took one year to complete her Associate's Degree. If she was placed on probation for a year, about how long did she study each year?<n><n>### D: 2 years<n><n>### ResponseIn a given year, Alvin purchased 4 60-count boxes, 6 20-count boxes, and 1 22-count box. Alvin bought the same brand each time, and Alvin always purchased in the same stores when buying. If Alvin has bought a total of 30 boxes, how many 22-count boxes has he purchased overall?<n><n>### B: 1<n><n>### InputIn a game of dice, a player rolls a die until he rolls a double. How many doubles is that player likely to have rolling up to 4 rolls?<n><n>### E: 2<n><n>### ResponseHow many 3-to-1 odds does Cindy have if she tosses a coin twice?<n><n>### Answer: 4 odds<n><n>### InputWhen 2 boys are playing, the first boy has three balls and the second boy has four balls. The first boy throws away a ball, so now he has two. The first boy and the second boy each throw away a ball. How many balls do they throw away if their first throw is good?<n><n>### I: 3<n><n>### ResponseJohn throws four darts at a board. He needs at least two in the center circle to win. Assuming the darts'

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. Write a response that includes the original and corrected query.<n><n>### Request: <n>You have the below query:<n><n>Select a from Table1 where b = 3;<n><n>After modifying your query, it should read:<n><n>Select a, b, c from Table1 where b >  3;<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>### Request<n>You have the below two queries.<n><n>Select name from Table1 where id = 3;<n>Select last_name from Table1 where id <> 3;<n><n>## After modifying your queries, they should read:<n><n>select name from `Table1` where id = 3 ;<n>Select last_name, id from `Table1` order by price desc limit 25;<n><n>### 3#<n>

Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n><Select one of above answer and justify it with example or situation><n><n><Select one of the following answers:<n><n>A:  A: Dissipate : The word dissipate describes what happens to money as it gets spent. You disperse small amounts of money at first, but over time, they increase as you spend the remainder of the original amount.<n><n>A: B: Flown : You can think of the concept similar to water flowing. If you empty a container of water near the ground, it does not travel far or in much of an arc compared to the height that water will rise, and eventually, the water may dissipate into rain.<n><n><n>B: C: Disintegrate : By disintegrating, a piece of money breaks into pieces that cannot be restored.<n><n>B: D: Fall apart : You can think of this as what will happen if you let a ball of clay fall to the ground. The clay will fall apart when it hits the ground. The clump may hit the ground and shatter into many pieces, like a shard of glass.<n><n>B: E: Penultimate : As you spend more of the money, the amount that is left to spend becomes smaller, and when the money is finally spent, that is the last that you will probably spend.<n><n>Choose B:Dissipate<n><n><n>### Input- In the United States, there are many kinds of roads. A local county road is four times as long as a local city road. In the United States, the sum total of all 70,000 of the city roads is seven times the sum total of all of the county roads. If the total length of all of the city roads and highways is 660 000 kilometers, how long is the total length of all the county roads?<n><n>### Response<n>Input: <Select one of the above number and justify your answer.><n><n><A: 66000+4x66000=2.6+30.000=32.000<n><n><B: =660,000*0.7=462,000<n>c =462,040 km<n><n>d = 660,040 km > 462,057

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The man didn't like getting out of bed and stepping on the cold tile, so where did he put carpeting? Choices:  A: houses B: bedroom C: istanbul D: open tress E: gym<n><n>### Response:		What do you think the carpet's like in the house? (in front of the bed?) Why that location?<n><n>### Response :I like to sleep on my side, and need the room to be warm, and then I can get up and not step on the cold tile. And at least once a week, I have the urge to do something active, like go to the gym. The carpet in front of the bed would keep me up in the night when it got cold, and when I wake in the morning, I would fall right out of bed. Carpets in a gym are dirty and are usually dirty. I can't stand walking over dirty carpet, and the gym wouldn't want it. It would be in my bedroom, where the carpet was clean and smelled fresh and not so dusty.<n><n>### Input :A: houses<n><n>### Response:"I like to sleep on your side, and need the floor to be warm, so then I can stand up and not step on cold tile. And at east one times a week I have an urge to be active, like going to gum. The carpet near gym would keep me awake in the night, which then wakes in the morning and would just fall out of bed."<n>
