Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n><n>### Response:		<n>Michigan - Michigan was known as the "Great Lake State" back around 1835. The reason for this was that Michigan was the only state that had two peninsulas separated by the Great Lakes.  The northern part of the state is mostly forest and woodland, filled with many lakes, rivers, and streams. Michigan is sometimes known as the "Land of Ten Thousand Lakes". The land was once covered by glaciers but were formed when the glaciers retreated; leaving the remains of rocks and debris behind.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Please answer all questions using only the knowledge gained from the article "How to write a high school mathematics paper".<n>### Demonstation:<n><n>    ### Example 1:<n>    Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>    ## Answer:<n>    ## Demonstration: Pete walked 1 blocks from his house to catch the bus. He walked 20 blocks to school. How many blocks did he walk in all?<n>    > Question : How many blocks did he cover?<n>    > Answer : 30<n>    <n>    ## Example 2:<n>    Instruc<n>    ## Answer: A:<n>    ## Dem<n>    ## De<n>    ## m<n>    ## st<n>    ## ra<n>    ## tion:<n>    ## Michigan was known as the Great Lake State back around 1823. The reason for this is that Michigan is the only state that have a lot of farmlands.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If you harm property after starting a fire where are you likely to end up? Choices:  A: damage B: going to jail C: going to school D: burns E: destruction<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is:<n>Input: 150 cards<n>Output: 221 cards<n><n>Input: 9 (15 -6) + 40 = 50<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EQY2wlYU8AA1RiO.jpg)<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>In a classroom, there is 211 total cards.<n><n>There are (10 + 20 + 13 + 6) = 49 thermoses and (9 + 3) = 12 thermoses.<n><n>Voltaire has (50 + 50)/2 = 25 viewers per day<n><n>After paying his debts, he is left with 9 dollars total.<n><n>When Jimmy grows his vegetables, he is left with a total of 4,055 servings.<n><n>150 M&M candies divided by 3 Starburst candy is 50 Starburst candy<n><n>Output: 50<n>

You cant buy them in a car, house or bedroom, because there are no drug storage places in these places, drugstores are only places in which drugs are sold. You never buy hairbrushes in a house or any other place either. Maybe you buy it in a car, but not in a bedroom.<n>

Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: happiness D: being entertained E: walk slowly<n><n>### Response:		Choices: "D" and "E"<n><n>### Input:[I got 7 of these and 5 of these.](https://www.wowmath.com/solutions/4a-plus8a.html)<n><n>### Input:"How much does Jane make per week? A: $50 B: $4500 C: $460 D: $4060"<n><n>### Response:"D"<n><n>### <n><n>### Input:{How long does it take to drive from Houston to Austin?}(https://www.wowsays.com/lessons/51.html)<n><n>---<n>### Input:"WowSays", how many days per week are there? (3rd Grade)<n><n>Input: A=2,B=[2,3]<n>Output: 2*[true,true]<n><n>### Input:(https://www.womath.com/solutions.html?q=2+3)<n><n>### Instriction:(https://www.fairygodboss.com/articles/examples-of-mathematical-proofs-that-you-can-apply-to-your-career)<n><n>### This task is about solving linear equations.(https://www.flipcard.com/solved-math-problems/)<n><n>### This is about solving a linear equation.(https://www.wized.byu.edu/solving-linear-equations/)<n><n>### Instutcion:"WowMath", the sum of two prime numbers is the same as the

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer from the dropdown is choice (E).<n>### Instruction : If Marla can deliver flowers that are twice as many as Alyssa’s, and Marnie can deliver twice Alyssa’a, how many can Marnie and Marla deliver altogether if they are trying to deliver three times more than Alyssa?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: If Marla can deliver 3 times as many flowers as Alyssa and Mara can deliver twice as many flowers as Aylssa then how many can Marla and Mara deliver altogether if they are delivering three times flowers as Alyssawant to do?<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task.<n>### Demonstation:<n>Input: Alyssa owns 3 times as many stuffed bears as her twin brother. You may notice that they also have many plastics in their cupboard.<n><n>### Further Explanation:You can use the word "having" or "has' to answer this question.<n><n>## Other resources:<n>* <https://www.codecademy.com/classes/mathematical-reasoning-csr/lessons/logical-reasoning-multiple-choice-questions><n><n>* <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1559701/how-do-i-make-an-array-the-same-size-as-another-array-in-javascript>

Input: A farmer plants 4 beans for every 3 corn, 6 cucumbers for every 5 cabbage, and 8 onions for every 5 tomatoes. If he plants 2,500 of each vegetable how many of each vegetable does he have?<n>Answer: Output: Input: A farmer plans 4 beans for each of 3 corn, 5 cabbage of every 6, and 8 tomato for every 5 onions. If he has 2500 of each of the four vegetables how many of each vegetables does he have?<n>Answers: Explanations: 1. How 4 beans are 4 beans, and how 3 corn are 3, so 4 beans -------------- 3 corn is 1 and since he adds ------------- 1, it equals 1 as the same answer.<n>2.How many 5 cabbage are 2,505 / 6 = 2509, then he has 2,509 / 5 = 501,8 which means that he has 501+505 so he has 1006 or he has 10 corn.<n>3. The same method as above 1, we do --------------- 1 and therefor as the same answer. 4.The same method as above 2, how he plants are 1048 / 5 = 209,6 which means he has 209+205=414 or have 4 beans.<n><n>### Input：You are working in a construction site. Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n><n>### Response:		Answer choice:<n><n>E:dirty dishes<n>### Why?<n><n>The second sentence of the introduction begins with a conjunction, "So," indicating that it serves as a transition between two statements. In that section, there is mention of "a pile of what" and "a cleaner breakfast"--that the second sentence is responding to the what that has been piled up with eating breakfast leads us to think the response should be describing that, not just listing it.<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where you have finished a conversation with a person what do you say? Marry is Mabel's sister 3. Jim is Alice's husband 4. Alice and Mabel's sons are cousins<n><n>### Response :The correct answer should be Jim is Alice's husabnd and he is related to Alice.<n><n>###Solution:<n>1. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What business uses lots of potatoes? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: vegetable market C: ireland D: produce market E: dessert spot<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where can you find pamphlets regarding diseases and ailments? Choices:  A: theaters B: health department C: library D: drawer E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices lettered A & D are correct. The pamphlets are <n>available at all hospitals that have an infirmary. In the<n>United States, pamphlets can be found at A&D drug stores,<n>and all clinics have handouts to distribute. In Canada, they<n>can be found at pharmacies and at the front desk of the<n>pharmacy. <n><n>### Instructions:Which one of the following is an example of a logical consequence?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A & C are incorrect. A & C are not logical consequences.<n><n>### Question: Which of these answers should go first in a multiplication word problem? Choices: A: group first B: groups first<n>C: grouping first D: grouping sets first E: multiples first <n><n>### Response A & B: is incorrect. The order of multiples should be the least complex, as it is the grouping sets and the multiples.

I'm sure at least a few people have difficulty expressing themselves  using proper grammar.<n><n>I hope the above paragraph was helpful.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Bill bought an upright piano but didn't have anywhere to put it because he lived where? Choices:  A: band B: music room C: college D: university E: house<n><n>### Response:		Bill has 2 choices, but one fits both.<n><n>### Description:This is a multi-select question requiring either band or college as answer choices.<n><n>### Inputs:Bill has bought a piano but doesn't have where to put it.<n><n>### Process:Use either band or college for your answer.<n><n>### Output:Bill has bought either band or college.<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>---<n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Description<n><n>This is a task where the question is answered by multiple options and the user must select the option which best applies to the problem statement.<n><n>### Solution 1:Python, Pandas<n><n>```<n>solution_1 = {<n>    "title":"Multiple select question",<n>    "language":"python",<n>    "code":`import pandas as pd<n>from numpy import nan<n><n>df2 = pd.DataFrame(data={"a":["1", "100", nan], "b":["20", 97, nan], "c":[nan, nan, nan]})<n><n># Select first entry per group<n>df1 = df2.groupby(["a", "b"]).sum().rename_axis("", axis="columns")<n><n>df2.set_index("", inplace=True).join(df1.set_index("a"))<n><n>for x in df2.index.unique():<n>    print(f"- {x} | " + df2[x+"_1"].mean() + "\n")<n>`<n>}<n>```<n>

She spends 5% of her salary for rent in New York. Her salary is $40,000 and her rent is $2000 in New Jersey. She buys milk and eggs at the store for $2 each. How much money does Sally have left?<n><n>### Delivery:<n>```<n>- 460<n>- 900<n>- 640<n>- 250<n>```<n><n>## Expected Inputs/Expected Outputs<n>- 1 statement/1 answer<n>- 1 statment/1 answer<n>-<n>- 1 input/1 output<n><n>### Demographics:Average 10-year-olds in the US have an IQ of 100. How much higher is the average IQ of 16-year-olds in Switzerland vs 10-year olds in the US.  <n><n>### Expected Output<n>```<n>- 0<n>- 0<n><n>- 15.5 points<n>- 43.5 points<n>```<n><n>## Restaurant Scam<n><n>### Inputs:The Restaurant Scam has four steps: Make reservations, make dinner, make the payment, and walk away.<n><n>### Steps:<n>- Make Reservations:<n>    - - Call and make reservations for a restaurant and ask for a table.<n>- Have Dinner:<n>    - - Arrive at the restaurant.<n>- Pay:<n>    - - Present a fake check on the table.<n>    - - Ask for the tip.<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>0<n>```<n> <n>## Mixed Fractions<n>### Inputs/Outputs:<n>##

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		<n>Pick the best choice from given options:<n><n>A: wishing well<n><n>B: kitchen<n><n>C: hardware store<n><n>### Required Output:<n>Answer: B,kitchen<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>* Choices are not random!<n>* Pick the best choice from given possibilities and write appropriate answer!<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a function called janitor-pick-pail-out-of-where that takes the input as the janitor's pail's original location and returns the janitor's new place.<n><n><n>---<n><n>### Instructon: Input the following numbers:<n>* 300<n>* 350<n>* 500<n>* 800<n><n>---<n><n>* 728<n>* 900<n><n>### Write a function called Janet's-Grocery-Bill that takes the amount of groceries and the tax on the groceries.<n><n>---<n><n>Input Janet's groceries: 400 kg of bananas, 300 kg of apples, 100 kg of cheese, and 100 kg tomatoes and the tax: 20% total.<n><n>* How much was the tax?<n>* How much was Janet's grocery bill?<n><n>---

Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option A and B are incorrect because their opposites are thoughtful and discreet respectively. They are not logical answers. Option C is incorrect because the opposite of foolhardily is the same as foolhardily which is not a word.<n><n>Option D and E are correct because the opposite of foolheaded is careful as we can see in the dictionary:  foolish (fəʊl) adj. Slow to learn or understand. <n><n>f00L.H64D|.s01m<n><n>Input:In three-quarters of all families, the father is older than his children. If the father is at least twice as old as his child, the child is not living with his parents. If this is true, how old is the father of a family of five children?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question.<n><n>## Instruction: How can you tell the age of a girl of 18?<n><n>## Instruction Answer:<n>The girls age is determined by her name. One would not guess her age from the number of letters in her name. Girls who are 18 have a unique combination of letters in their names.<n><n>### Code Challenge for the day:<n>Write a program that prompts the user to enter a string of up to 50 characters. For each word (except the string at the end) which contains only letters and no punctuation, the program should print the number of letters in that word. For example, if the string were "mr. tommy", the program should print 4 followed by a newline character. If the string were "fine", the program should print "one letter" followed by a newline character because there is only one letter in the string "fine". <n>

Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### What it will do:<n>It finds the number of people who are standing on a line near the road.<n><n>### Why it does it:<n>Standing on a line near the roads, the people go to the apartment, bus stop, military base and fire house.<n><n># 1.3 Instruction:Read the following passage carefully and then answer the questions asked at the end.<n><n>### Passage:Every year, my grandfather would bring us to the zoo. There, we usually visited the polar bear enclosure.  The polar bears often swam toward us until their noses hit the glass. I remember the polar bear's face as it appeared through the glass, a large black nose and eyes staring at us.  Another time, there were four polar bears in the enclosure. They were chasing after each other back and forth, as if they were playing. They would make turns until they were right in front of us like they were going to charge us.  I remember one time they did charge. This time, though they had a large group of bystanders with them, so it wasn't as dangerous as when it was just us. They circled around us and then made a turn to stop by the glass. When they walked by, they looked right at us. I looked back at them as if they were looking at me.  One time, I noticed their paws. When I looked back, I could see the top of their paws through the glass as they walked past. One of the polar bears paws wasn't perfectly round. In fact, it was bent and I could see its claws. They were sharp enough to cut through a polar bear's prey. This was the only time I ever saw a polar bear up close and personal.<n><n>### Questions:<n>Which of the following is not mentioned in the passage? Choices: A: there wasn't any bear to see B: there were some things that I saw through the glass C: my grandfather brought us to the zoo D: I saw a polar bear through the glass<n><n>### Answer:  A<n><n>### Why:<n>It is not mentioned in the story.<n><n>### What:<n>A polar bear's paws weren't perfectly round. It was bent and I could the see its claws through the glass.<n><n>##

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If a person does something to hurt someone else, they might do what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answers to exercise problems could be multiple choice, fill in the blank, or true or false statements. Exercise responses, therefore, should be presented in a format that matches the exercise answers.<n><n>```<n>A. answer, which will be written on a line below the sentence.<n><n>```<n><n>### Input 2:If 4 is 15 what is 65? Choices: 43 31 18 4 0 1<n><n>### Response 2:<n>For number problems, the answer should be written in numbers with no decimal points. For example, `4` would be written as `4` and `15` as `15.` In contrast, the answer to the `43` problem would be written as `015` because it has a decimal point to show 43/100.`<n><n>```<n><n>A. answer, written on separate line(s) below<n>```<n><n>## :boom: Exercise<n><n>### Multiple Choice:<n>Choose the best answer to the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Exercise 1:<n>Sally's father is 4 times her age. Her uncle is also 4 times her age but is younger than her father. Sally is 8 years old. Her father's age is...<n><n>A. 24<n><n>B. 36<n><n>C. 12<n><n>D. 48<n><n>#### Answer:<n>Let's set up the formulas as a simple multiplication equation.<n><n>So:<n><n>Sally's age/age of her father = 1/4<n><n>Sally' age * (1/4) = 8<n><n>Sally' father will also equal 8<n><n>### Exercises 2:<n>A car travels down a long street and reaches a point where it turns a corner. The car driver records 1.5 seconds as having passed between the moment the car turned the corner and the moment the speedometer read 60 miles per hour. If the car has a mass of 2,000 kilograms and an acceleration of 32 feet per second squared, how far were the wheels from the spot where the corner was turned when 60 miles per second was read? To the nearest hundredth of 10

Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		"D - small group"<n><n>### Explaination: (You know, "the rest of the story" 😊)<n><n>So, I thought the answer would be "small group" but I wasn't sure and I wasn't thinking about it the right way.  At one point, I thought the answer was "solitude" because they said it wasn't "big".  They also said the crowd could be better described as "solitude".  Well, small groups have what's best described as a "solitude", that solitude is called privacy.  That is why you should always try to keep your private information private.  <n><n>### Instructions:  Read the sentences below and answer the questions that follow.  Then answer the questions 1-4.  Each question has a number of multiple-choice options.<n><n>The girl is reading a book. I do not know where the girl has come from. The boy is playing with a toy. The girl also plays with a toy. I am playing with toys too. I like the toy the best. The boy and the girl are playing with my toy. What does the verb "to be" modify in each of  these sentences?<n>Answer: The verb "to be" modifies "playing with"<n><n>### Instructors: Answer the multiple choice questions 1-4<n>Answer: The answer to 1 is the boy because the verb "to be''modifies playing with the toy. The answer to 2 is the girl because the verb "to read" modifies reading the book.  The answer to 3 is the boy because the "to be" modifier modify playing.  And the answer to 4 is the girl because "to be" modiferates playing.<n><n>### Input : "I will do my homework tomorrow and I will not eat sweets." B: If 12 is divisible by 7, 238 is divisible by 3, and 5677 is divisible by 5, what is (100 X 6)? A: B: C: D: E: <n><n>### Response A: The correct answer is 60.<n><n>### Input<n>If the area of a square is x² and the sides of a rectangle with the same perimeter are 2x and 2x + 2 then what is the area of the rectangle? Choices: 1: x² - (x + 1)^2 2: 2x x + 4 3: 2x (x + 1) - (x + 2)^2 4: (x + 2)x - 4x^2 + (x + 1)*2(x + 1)<n><n>### Response 2) The correct equation is 2x (x+1)- (x+2)^2<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following problem.<n><n>### Task 2: Calculate the following expressions<n>Find the value of: x^3-2x^2<n><n><n>## Problem 5<n>## Input<n>Find the value of the following expressions:<n><n>`A. x^3 + x^2 + x -1`<n><n>`B. 18*(12 + x)`<n><n>`C. 8 - (5x - 2)/(7+3^2)`<n><n>`D. (4x^8)*(12+2x^7)`<n><n>`E. (4x^6 - 6x^5)/(x^3 - 6x^2)`<n><n><n><n>## Response:<n><n>```python<n>X3 = 10*x**3<n><n>A = X3 + 2*x**2 + x - 1<n><n>B = 18*(10+x)<n><n>C = x**2 - (5*(5*x**4)) + 8<n><n>D = x**5(4*x**3) + (12+2*x**

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		If you don’t get the answer you didn’t do anything wrong, you learn something, and you just have more practice with a math problem.<n><n>### Input-Grammar:In the previous question, what word would you write?<n><n>### Response-Grammar:Answer: I would write something<n><n>### Input :Practice filling in the missing words to create an adjective from given words.<n><n>### Response :In the beginning, and during the course of learning mathematics, there is a period when a student feels incapable of performing the tasks he/she is asked to do. It can be because of many reasons.<n>One of which can be because he/she has not adequately acquired the material to handle the task, or cannot even remember the necessary formula. Sometimes, students suffer from math phobia, an irrational fear of performing or even thinking about problems from that field of study. Sometimes, the root cause of the problem is ineffective teaching.<n>Mathematics, in and of itself, is a simple science. It doesn’t need to be so difficult. All someone has to do is pick up a piece of paper and get started: write down the question, set it aside, and then come back later to the first page.<n>In the first few attempts, people tend to give up. They are too afraid of the wrong answer. This is when they should focus on just getting the right answer.<n>At the end of the day, that is what it’s all about: the right answer and how to get it.<n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What should you do if your pens aren't work? Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n><n>### Response:		What should you do if your pencils aren't working?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A: ink B: caps C:increase font by half the size<n>Output:C<n><n>### Demisturction<n>- There were two choices that were incorrect.<n>- A and C had the correct choices.<n>  - A: decrease font D: ink cartridig<n>```<n>{						   <n>	"choiceSet": {					          <n>		"a": {		             <n>			"probability": 15      <n>		},	<n>		"b": {	              <n>			"explanation": 192,    <n>			"choice": "c",     <n>			"type": 1034   <n>		},		<n>		"c": {		         <n>			"properChoice": 4,   <n>			"priorProbability": 15, <n>			"choices": ["b", "d", "f"]      	 <n>		},	  <n>		"probabilityOfOutcomes": { 15, 193, 256, 363 }<n>```<n><n>### 1 Input: <n>1. How often does 1-3 work together?<n><n>2. How often does 4-7 work together?<n><n>  { <n>    "inputPairs": { <n>        "1-3": { "38", "42", "69" }, <n>        "4-7": {} <n>    } <n>  }<n><n>  ## Demostration: <n><n>  A. 1 - 3: always together because 9 -17 is always together<n>  B. 2 - 7: if both sides are greater than 1 or less than 7, they are together<n>  C. 1 - 7 is rarely together<n><n>  ## The answer is 1 -7 is rarely together because the 3 values are rarely together but 1 and 3 and 3 and 7 are frequently together.<n><n><n>### 2 Input:<n>  A. What would happen if you multiply any number greater than or

Choices:<n>A: get arrested<n>B: problems<n>C: sober<n>D: intoxication<n>E: pleasure<n>### Response: E: pleasure<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>You will see several commands. Write a response that completes the request if it involves a conditional statement. otherwise (if not) ignore or comment.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>1# If n<100<n><n>### Instructoin:<n>If two conditions are true, make the if statement false and the else statement true. If one but not the other is true, make both statements false.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demo<n>If n<100 or x=2 <n>n=20<n>else: <n>n=40<n><n>### Demo2<n>If k>=1:<n>k-1<n>else:<n>k-1+9<n><n>### Instruptions:<n><n>What would this code tell the computer to do if the statement were true?<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1. <n>k:=10<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Code<n>k := 20<n>### Demo: <n>If k>=1 (false)<n>k := 18<n><n>### Demo 2:<n>If k>=10 (false)<n>k:= 8<n>### Demo: If k>=10(true)<n>k:= 22<n>### Demo: if k>=10(false)<n>k :=27<n><n><n><n>## <n>### Demonstation<n>### Demo:if n>=10<n>k:=(10 - n)<n>n=9<n>if j=10:<n>k:=n<n>else<n>k:=n-j<n>### Demonsteration 2:<n>### Input n <= 10<n>### Demo 1:<n>If y=4:<n>z:=n-y<n>n=6<n>else:<n>z := n-y+y<n>n = 10<n>## Demo 2:<n>## Demo 1 <n>if y = 5:<n>z := n - y <n>n=2<n>else:<n>z:= n - y

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. By clicking on a button labeled "share", the sharing of the file will be initiated.<n><n>### Input :<n>A) The first digit and last digit of a number are even, and each digit after that is one greater<n>than the digit before it.<n><n>How many digits are there the number?<n><n>A) There are only 3 digits in the number.<n><n>B) The first digit and the last digit are the same, then each digit after that is 1 greater than the digit before it. What are the last two digits of the number?<n><n>B) 7, 4<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the questions that follow.<n><n>1. Which is faster: the first step or the last step?<n>the first<n><n>2. If 4-5th digit is added to the first 4-hundred number, and the result is 4730, then the first number will be:<n>112<n><n>3. If the first digit, the second digit, the third digit, and the fourth digit are each the third digit of a number, the first digit will be:<n>6<n><n>4. If one day is 4 weeks and one week is 6 days, then in one year:<n>17760 days<n><n>5. Which of the following pairs have the same number of units?<n>6. The 50th digit is 10, the 1054th digit is 07, and the 2534th digit is 7. Can you deduce a pattern?<n>The pattern repeats as the number becomes larger.<n><n>### Output:<n>The output would read:<n><n>The first digit in the number is 1, the second digit is 1, the last digit is 1. Therefore, there are three digits in the number. The last two digits are 2 and 00.<n><n>The first digit is 4, it is added to 6 to create 10. One digit is added after each number.<n>The first digit is even, therefore the answer would be 4.<n><n>In 4730<n>The fourth digit is 7, 310 (the first number) + 311 (the second number) + 320 (the third number) + 4

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Though he could've kept going his body appreciated the rest, it had been constantly what during the day? After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult.  Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n># [E]<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Create a function that takes in an array, and a second array that contains all of the distinct numbers within the first array.  Your function should have the following code signature: `print_distinct_numbers_from_array(arr1, arr2)`<n><n>### Output:<n>    arr<n><n>### Input<n><n>arr = [0, 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]<n><n>### Output<n><n>[2, 3, 5, 7, 9]<n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>Your code should follow the same structure for the first and for the second input, but the output values will vary.  The first time you should print the values in the array directly as a list.  The second time you should first print a list of all the distinct numbers in the input array, and then print those distinct numbers in the output array.<n><n>### Notes<n><n>* This function is about doing the same thing twice, which is why the code signature looks the way it does.<n>* This is a great way to improve your general Python skills, as function parameters can be anything.  It's also a great chance to think through best practices for your output.<n><n>### Hint<n><n>Look at the output of arr and arr_distinct_numbers, and think about the logic behind them.<n><n>### Resources:<n><n>[Codecademy](www.codecademy.com, section 21, module 3: arrays).<n><n>### Code of Conduct<n><n>This document serves as our code of conduct (https://github.com/caringtechies/resources/blob/master/about/code_of_conduct.md), so take note!<n><n>### Discussion<n><n>Please share with your classmates any questions and/or tips about this challenge.<n><n>### Feedback<n><n>We encourage you to seek out feedback.  Feel free to open a pull request to your classmate's solution and let them know what you think.<n><n>If you need help, email us at hello@caringtechies.org, and you can also leave your code or a description of it in a message in our Slack.

Mary loves singing and she is very good at it.<n><n>To combine the sentences, remove the word, "and". <n><n>Now, the sentence will say, **"Mary loves singing and is very good at it."** <n><n>**Formal<n><n>**Use formal words and phrases as shown in the examples: “you,” “your,” “my,” “our,” “mine,” “I,” “me,” “you,” “him,” “her,” “my,” “her,” “it,” “my,”<n><n>**Irregular Plurals Formation of Plural Nouns as shown in examples:<n><n>**Historical person: Columbus is from Italy.<n><n>**Irregualar plural: scissors is a pair of scissors.<n><n>**Iritabal plural: the people is people.<n><n>**Possesive Noun<n><n>To indicate ownership, in the plural, add's:<n><n>**Our class is playing dodge ball.<n><n>**The children's room is next to our room.<n><n>**The woman's hat is made in France.<n> <n>**Combine sentences to add a sense of urgency: She wants to travel. She was very excited about traveling.<n><n>**Complete the response<n><n>**Whenever you are unsure about how to format an email, ask the teacher or coach. How many seconds does Annabelle and Betty play individually?<n>Answer 1: 6<n>Answer 2: 210<n>### Player 2<n>Annabelle is playing against both Betty and Catherine.  Betty and Catherine each play for 10 seconds.  Betty and Catherine give Annabelle an extra second to play.  After Betty and Catherine play, Annabelle gets twice as many seconds in time as she gave to each of Betty and Catherine.  How many seconds to each player play individually after adding their extra seconds?<n>### Player 3<n>Anne has 3/4 of the amount of time that Annie plays for.  For every second Annie plays, Anne does not have to wait as long to play.  If they each play for 15 seconds, how long does Anne wait to play?<n>### Player Question 4<n>Anne, Betty, Catherine, and Diane play a game. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:James felt himself losing consciousness.  He was frightened.  He didn't want this.  He was scared of what? Choices:  A: death B: coma C: peace D: forgetfulness E: loss of life<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is D: loss of life<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		John's nose.<n><n>### Inputs:Linda can type a little fast. Today, she had to type 31.8 keys per second and only typed 30.9. This was bad because she had a job to complete. She had to type 44.5 keys per second. For every 3 girls, there are 7 more boys. If the class has 320 students in all, how many children are in all?<n><n>### Response :  <n>If this is true, it means we have an equation : there are 20 boys, for every 3 girls we have 7 more, if in total we have 320 people we can see that there are 20 x 3 = 60 women, if we add the 7 we get 67, but in total of 320 which is the answer.<n><n>### Your response<n><n>[Click here to reply](https://github.com/Dominic-Lara-Ramos/Python-Project/blob/main/Project-Files/Daily-Exercise/ex1--instruction.md)<n><n>### Discussion<n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is Home<n><n>### Input:[An adult needs ____. Choices: 1: to think 2: to breathe 3: to sleep 4: food 5: money] What does an adult need?<n><n>### Response:(2) Adults Need to Breathe<n><n>### Input:(A school has 341 students. A parent asks: What is 62% of the students at this school? What should be his answer?<n><n>### Reponse:It is incorrect to say it is 72 students. 62% of 341 is less than 62% of (n) which is n -.62n<n><n>### InputA: A school has 342 students. A parent asks, "What is 75% of the students at a school? What should the parent's answer be?<n><n>### InputB: A classroom has 343 students. A parent asks What is 75% students in this classroom? What should the parent answer?<n><n>## InputC:  A classroom has 279 students. A parent asks If 75% of all classroom students go by bus, what percentage goes by car? What should the parent’s answer be?<n>### InputC’s answer should be 100% of the remaining percentage because only a minority of children use cars instead of buses<n><n>### InputD: How much does a cucumber cost in France?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>France(FRANCE)=Cucumber(CURCUMBER)<n><n>### Response(FRANCE)=CURCUMBER<n>### Input:-  Does France have the same metric system as the United States?<n><n>### AnswerIt is a lie because France is not the same metric system as that of the United State.<n>

Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If we are trying to attach something to it, we would choose to polish. It makes the surface easier to grip when we are attaching a new thing. Carve, Eat, and Petrify are only examples to make it beautiful and that's it. Polishing actually helps the attaching process.<n><n><n>### Input<n>There are 15 books in a box. 10 of the books are fiction, and 5 of the books are nonfiction.  The number of fiction books that are nonfiction is double the number of nonfiction books that are not fiction.  How many nonfiction books are not fiction in the box?<n><n>### Response<n><n>If you want to find the number of nonfictions that are not fiction in the whole box, you need to put a separate box for the nonfictions that is not fiction.  Then multiply 10 by 2 so that 20 is the number of fiction that is nonfiction. Then you get 10 * 5 / 10 is 5. So total of fiction is 15. Then 5 * 5 is 25. So, there are 25 nonfiction books are fiction. So, there are total 35 books in the box.<n><n><n>## Evaluation<n><n><n>### Reward<n><n>### Corrections:<n>We fixed two typos on the following lines:<n>	If Beatrix has 33 books, how many books in all do the three have?<n><n>		4.5 gallons, how many pints in all?<n><n>Corrected lines:<n>		if Beatrix has 36 books, how many books does the three have together? (There is double digit missing in the number 36)<n>		4.0 gallons of coffee, how many pints is it?

Then, click “Submit” if you are happy with your solution.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Problem 1: Write a function that performs the following transformation on a string passed as input:<n><n>* Remove the leading string, followed by 3 repeated characters, followed by a trailing string in the string passed as input. (Example: String passed as input: "aabbbccdddee". Removal results in: "abcd")<n>* Passing as string input "aabbbcccccdee" would yield "abcddee".<n>* The removed string can be as long as required (up to 300 characters).<n><n>### Problems 2: The input will be a vector. If element 0 in the vector is present, the output should be element 0, minus the element 0 value in the vector, and then element 1, minus the element 1 value of the vector. (Example: {5, -3, -1} --> {4, 2, 1}).<n><n>### Problem3: Write a function that will remove a string of certain characters in a string passed as input. For example, the string `Hello World!` passes as string input. String to be removed `Hello`. Input string is now `World!`. <n><n>### Problem4: Create a function that will take an array as input and return a new sorted array of those values. For example, an input array with the values: `[71, 0, 27]`, would return the sorted output as `0, 27, 71`.<n><n>## Additional Instructions: Complete this task in the format requested. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* What is the value of the letter 'E'? (What would be the value of it had the letter been "available")<n>* The value of "E" is either -A, B, C, or D<n>* The answer is either D or E depending on the context in the question. Choices: -A, -B, -C, -D, E (either A or B, or C or D, or E)<n><n>* The above answer is the answer to the question, but it's not one of the choices given.<n><n>* The answer to the original question: "Which of these would John rather do?" - is either A, B, or C.<n><n>* Choice C is 'prefer', therefore 'available' is the answer.<n>

Your variable is the same in each set.<n><n>**Problem 1:** $$2 \times \frac{1}{x} = 9$$<n><n>**Problem 2:** $\frac{2}{2x-1} = 1$<n><n>**Problem 3:** $\frac{0}{0x+2} = 0$<n><n>**Problem4:** $\frac{5x-2}{2x+5} = 1$ <n><n>**Problem 5:** $\frac{4x-3}{x+2} = \frac{2}{3}$ <n><n><n><n>## SOLUTION:<n>| Problem | Solutions |<n>| ------- | -------- |<n>| Problem 1 | $$\frac{1}{2}$$ |<n>| Problem 2 | $$\frac{13}{1}$$ |<n>| Problem3 | $$\frac{0}{0}$$ |<n>| Problem4 | $$\frac{5x-3}{x}$$|<n>| Problem 5 | $$\frac{4x-2}{x}$$ <n><n>## Instruccion: Complete each expression for the given variables. Assume variables are distinct. One day, they learned ten new words. The other day, they learned 25 new words.  On Thursday, Nisha’ s teacher tests on two vocabulary words from each day of the week, including 5 words she learned two days ago, 10 words she learned last Monday, 15 words she learned two weeks ago, 20 words she learned last Friday, and 25 words she learned Monday of this week. How many words can Nisha know? (Do not include the five words she will not be tested on.)<n><n>### Input - Choices<n><n>A: 90, B: 100,   C: 190, D: 230,   E: 245<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input – Choices<n><n>A) Diane has a 44.8% probability of being taller than her brother Robert. B) Diane has a.032 probability of being taller. C) Robert has a 0.959 probability of being taller D) Diane has a > 0.5 probability that she is one half the height of Robert.<n><n>### Input  - Choices<n><n>D<n>	<n>### Instruactions<n><n>A. How is A related to this problem?<n><n>The probability that Diane is taller than Robert is 45.6% which is approximately equal to.45.<n><n>B. Is the probability of Robert being taller than Diane or is greater than or equal to the probability of Diane being taller than Robert?<n><n>No. The probability of Diane being shorter than Robert is less than 0.5 and we know that she is not shorter because we are told that she is taller, so therefore there has to be a probability of her being taller than him.<n>	<n>### Input 1<n><n>A. What is the probability of finding a 4 in both columns?<n>	<n>### Output 1<n><n>### Input- Choices<n><n>Diane is

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could a balalaika be needed for? Choices:  A: artist junkyard B: music store C: singing D: symphony E: orchestra<n><n>### Response:		It could be needed for a music store or symphony<n><n>### Input:-13 ÷ 6 = -2?<n><n>### Response:-13 ÷6 = -2<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could contain no more than around 100 people? The other answers are not given enough information.<n><n>**I am confused at the point of what should I do, or how I can better help myself or others.**<n><n>```<n>import time<n>import datetime<n>import uuid<n><n><n>start = uuid.uuid4()<n><n><n>for i in range(0, 3):<n>    name = input("Name : ")<n>    print(datetime.datetime.now())<n>    print(datetime_format = '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')<n>    current = i<n>    date = start + datetime.timedelta(minutes = i)<n>    now = time.time()<n>    print('The %s was created in %s by %s on %s' % (name, date.strftime("%H:%M:%S"), name, name))<n><n>    while(now - date < 3):<n>        name_new = input("Name :")<n>        new = current + 1<n>        date = start + datetime_diff(new, current)<n><n>        current = new<n>        now = time.time<n>        <n>        print('The "%s" was created by "%s" on %s' %(name_new,name, name_new))<n><n>    print('Name: ',name_new)<n>```<n>```<n><n>\* I am a student who has difficulties with: Math<n><n>### What you want to: Improve<n><n>I want to improve my typing skills to be able to keep up with the rest of the class.<n><n># What I did today<n><n>Today my code was able to show the creation times of each name I entered but the number of times each name is entered is not calculated, along with a different name each time. I also have trouble with reading the code that my teacher gives.<n><n># What is easy for me to learn<n><n>I have a very hard
