How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Why would a person be approached by a lot of people? Choices:  A: care about B: compliments C: know all D: popularity E: understand themselves<n><n>### Response:		B<n>

How many letters are in the alphabet?<n><n>Answer:26 Letters<n><n>### Instict: The second member of the alphabet is always one more than the first letter. Choices:  A: wooded area B: body of water C: the ocean D: british columbia E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>The beaver leaves the wooded area if it does not have enough time to be the size of a dog or a raccoon.<n><n>### Input:"Squirrels eat peanuts, and they are funny when they eat peanuts. "<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Squirrels don't eat peanuts.<n><n>### Response:" The word squirrels doesn't mean peanuts or eating peanuts."<n><n>### Input, Question:"The bus went underwater. What happened to the fish?"<n>### Demonstarion:<n>Nothing happened to the fish unless they were on a bus.<n><n>### <n>Input, Question:"If there were 3 apples in a bowl and 4 people ate 2 of the apples, then there would be no apples left."<n><n>### Demoaration:<n>The number of apples never fell below 1.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The word "if" means, "if and only if..." In other words, the statement is true if and only if 3 apples were in a bowl, and 4 people aced two of those apples. The apples never fell below one, no matter what.<n><n>### Question:<n>There is a big problem with solving word problems in math. How can this be prevented?<n><n>### Explanation:<n>You need to understand the numbers. You also need to understand the symbols like "and", "or", "times", "equals", "/", "+", etc.<n><n><n>### Response, 4 stars<n>"If you can understand a problem, answer the question, explain your thinking in an appropriate mathical notation, don't forget the "if and only if" symbol, etc. You will probably get 4 stars on all of the questions presented in this video."

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: believe in god B: pay bills C: group together D: enjoy themselves E: face each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input:-0.1 is less than -2, correct?<n><n>### Response:-0.1 is greater than 3, incorrect.<n><n>### Input:(7 – 5) • 2 = 35, correct?<n><n>

Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is a multiple choice question.<n>The statement that has to be completed is written below.<n>The response is: choice C.<n><n>The answer to this question is: choice C.  <n><n>Input:She wanted to make her own quilt and she remembered that she had to find lots of cloth of a certain texture. She wanted to make a quirk of velvet, where could she look? Choices(write your response here:):  A: grandma  B: clothing  C: jewelary store  D: clothes  E: fabric store<n>In this multiple choice question, we have 6 different choices of answers and the question is, where should she look for cloth that is quilt of velvet? Clothing store, fabric store, jewelary store, clothes store, or Grandma. If she wanted to find cloth for her quilt in grandma's house, her answer would be choice A. If she wanted to get them from a clothing store, then you would have to mark C instead of choice A. So in this situation, you would have to write choice C.<n>

After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C <n><n>### Input :What color is the light when it is first reflected off of the lamp? Choices:  A: own home B: old england C: new hampshire D: coffin E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		Choice "B"<n><n>### Inputs:Bill, Jack, and Lilly are all the same height. If Bill is 2 inches shorter than Lilly, how tall is Jack?<n><n>### Response1: Choice "C" - Jack is taller than Lilly by 2 inches, so if Bill is 2 inches short of Lilly, this means she is 2 inches above Bill so she must be 4 inches taller than Bill in total. Therefore the answer is choice "D" - Jack is 4 inches taller (2 more than Bill).<n><n>### Response2: Choice "A" - Since Bill is lower than Lilly, this means that Lilly is higher than Jack and therefore Bill. To solve we go up the hierarchy to know the level of the tallest. This is the answer A - Bill would be in his own home.<n>

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What does someone need to do to begin creating art? Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>#### Input: What is the most important characteristic an architect can possess? Choices: <n><n>#### Response: B<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>How many people went to the beach in the summer?<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>342<n>```<n><n>## Below is an instruction that asks a question about your understanding.<n><n>### Input  <h2>What are the best and worst parts about working with me?</h2><n><n>### Response  <h2><n>```<n>The best is that you are always willing to work with me. I really appreciate that you are able to work on problems even when you might want to avoid them.  <n>The worst is that the way I work can be a little annoying. I would like to ask you about how to work with me to make things just a little smoother. <n>```<n><n>## Input<n>#### Response<n>```<n>Low-Level Code<n>```<n><n>## Questions<n><n>### Below is a short paragraph from a work of fiction. Write an essay about what the author describes in the passage.<n><n>Alice thought he looked like the last person she wanted to see.<n>"Please, go away," she said.<n>She knew who it was in the doorway. It wasn't a dream.<n><n>This was the guy who ruined her chances with her first love.<n>She wanted to forget him...but she couldn't.<n>She wanted the pain to stop...but it didn't.<n><n>"Don't you know, we can't just walk away? I won't let you do that."<n>Alice stood motionless, not knowing what to do.<n>"He's not here," said a voice from inside.<n>The voice belonged to Michael, her brother.<n><n>This is a book that is very sad. It was very stressful to read. It didn't make sense for the brother to be inside while Alice was still outside. I think that was so that the author could build suspense and fear. She wanted to keep the reader on edge. The character Alice is very sad and angry. She is also frustrated by her situation. I would love to read other books by this author.  <n><n>### Below this is a short passage from a work of fiction you have read recently. Write an essay that describes what you

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		The man set the "cup" on the table.  He did not have anything to "balance" it. He did not have the "skill" to balance it. He must have used the "tenacity" that he has. The man did not have the "hands" to place the cup. He does not have the "hair" to balance it.<n><n>### Note<n><n>1. There can be 2 ways to answer the tasks<n>2. The answers should be unique (e.g. not be copied/pasted)<n>3. How much money is in each of their savings.<n><n>### Answer 1:51<n><n>### Write:(44) / (2222 + 1122 + 1022)<n><n>### Input <n>Alice and Emma go to the gymnastics center together where they meet up with Hannah for the first time, and are greeted by Jill who works there. Choices:  A: gathering of information B: communication C: feel relaxed D: kill boredom E: social bonding<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A<n><n>## Solutions<n><n>* Solution 1:<n><n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>count=input1 $* <n>echo $count<n>if [ $1 -gt $2 ]; then<n>    count=$1<n>else<n>    count=$2<n>fi  <n>echo $count/$2 > output2<n>if [[ $($count -ge $2) ]]; then<n>    echo yes;<n>    exit 0<n>else<n>    echo No; <n>fi<n>echo $count - $2 > output<n>exit 0<n><n>```<n><n>* Solution 2:<n><n>```<n>count=input1+input2<n>echo $?<n>echo 1 if ($count -ge $3)<n>echo $count/$3 > output3<n>if $count -ge $3; then<n>    echo yes<n>    exit 0 <n>else<n>    echo no<n>fi<n>echo $3 - $count > output2 <n>```<n><n>* Note: Solutions 1 and 2 are just sample solutions, you need to implement the logic of the instruction based on the given input <n><n>### Input<n>* The above input will be given as multiple input arguments. Use them appropriately<n>* The input will have 10 characters (variable length)<n>* Input will have 10 digits with 2 digits to start<n>* 2 digits will be the question number<n>* 8 digits will be the input to the task in one column<n>* The output will be 9 digits (10 digits in all)<n><n>### Solution<n>Using python to solve it<n><n>```python<n>#Write a python program to solve.<n>"""The python code is given below""" <n>import sys, math<n>while True: <n>    number = input() <n>    if number =='stop':<n>        break <n>    elif len(number) == 12: <n>        break <n><n>try: <n>    x = math.floor(int(number[:2])) <n>    y = int(number[2:][:-1]) <n>    z = math.floor(x/2) <n>    print('ans: '.center(30,''),) <n>    if x>2 and y>2 and (x==ceil(x/2)) and (y==ceil(y/2)):<n>        print(

For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you have to go to Tennessee, you'll find the fiddle because it's where fiddle is usually playing. You don't need me to spell out the answer. You are supposed to do this. <n><n>-Tennessee<n><n>### Input : In which of the following statements is "the" in the noun phrase interchangeable with "a" or "an"? Choices:<n>A)  "Can you get me an espresso?"<n>B) “Can you get me a car?”<n>C) "Can you get me a horse?"<n>D) “Can you get your sister an orchid?"<n>E) "Can you get your sister a horse?"<n><n>### Response :<n>In statement D, the noun phrase "An orchid for your sister" is an essential modifier that can not be left out. Interchange of a/an must be done between the main clauses in the same statement such as:<n><n>-Can you get me an orange? or  Can you get an apple?<n><n>-Can you order me a chicken sandwich? or Can you order an apple?<n>-Can you get a cat? or Can you get a dog?

How many floors did he go up or down on?<n>### Response:He went up on 14 floors.<n><n>### If the question says:<n>How many years will I have to work at $10/day if I earn $480/year and I get a raise of $30/year<n><n>### How do I know:<n>If I work for 1 year, I will earn 480. If I get a raise next year, I will earning 480 + 30 = 510. 510 - 10 = 490. If I work for 10 years, I will work for 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10. I'll earn 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55, 56, and 57 dollars/day/year. I will earn a total of 480 + x dollars/day/year where x = 18000. I will have to work 18001 days.<n>

He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		(Your choice should be appropriate and demonstrate mastery of these instructions, using proper punctuation, capitalization, spelling, and grammar.)<n><n>### Sample response 1<n>>A: (Answer: Store)<n>>	<n>>After a long day, the student headed straight to the stationary to pick up a few new pencils for school.<n><n>### Sample Response 2<n>>A: (C: Classroom)<n>>	<n><n>>To get new pencils, the student would go to the stationary at the back of the classroom.<n><n>### Sampling response 3<n>>C: (C: Classrom)<n>>	<n>

Choices:  A: illiterate B: knowledgable C: own house D: have enough food E: meet expectations<n><n>### Response:		Choice,E<n><n>### Demand:Explain how you determined your choice in response from the request.<n><n>In the above request, the words to the right of "what is" is the name of the person who is described (a person who is well educated).<n>When a choice follows this, the choices are choices that describe the name that is to the right of "is". We want to choose a choice that would apply to someone who is well educated.<n>For the choices, we know that (A and B) describe an illiterate person or a person who is not well educated. (C) is a person who owns a house; (D) is a person who has food enough; (E) is the person who meets expectations.<n><n>### Comments<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The president had to make a decision regarding the hate attack on his country, what did he do? Choices:  A: wage war B: fight enemy C: kill D: destroy enemy E: attacked his country<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>Due to the magnitude of the hate attack, the president chose to eliminate the threat by  ***attacking his country.***.<n><n>### Input A:<n><n><n>**You are the 22nd student I have interviewed.**<n><n>**T**o complete the interview, please write **a** sentence that starts with "I don't know..." <n><n>Input B:<n><n>**I don't know why you interviewed many students before me**<n><n>### Input B:<n>It may be difficult for you<n><n>### Response B:<n><n><n>It is ***difficult for you***.<n><n>## Contributed by<n>  [Aditi](https://github.com/Aditi2586119)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? Choices:  A: dream B: fiddle C: watch film D: see new E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n>E Work<n><n>### Credit:Abraham Mengistea<n>

He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Choices:  A: cafeteria B: arranging papers C: in the park D: formal dining room E: house<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple choices correctly<n><n>### Input : A. A: In the park B: arranging papers  C : cafeteria D: in the park E: house <n><n>### Answer:E<n><n>### Instuctions:Write the following sentence accurately by replacing the underlined words or phrases with words or phrases from the choices<n><n>### Input  :  I went to the grocery store to buy a ham to give to a special someone. I had to choose from two different brands: Virginia Pride Select and Gwaltney. <n><n>### Response  :  I went in the grocery store shopping for a ham to give to my friend as an act of kindness. I had to decide between two brands: Virginia Prite Select and Gwaltney<n><n>### Instraction :  I was asked if I would like to see a film at the weekend.<n><n>### Answer  : Yes, that is something I would like.<n><n>### Input   : Jackie asked her husband if she could see the movie. She asked for 6 tickets to see the movie on Friday night.  Jack was on business on Friday and did not have time to go see the movie.  But he said it would be okay to buy the tickets and maybe later he and Jackie could get together for the movie.  Jack was on a business trip from 10:00am until Friday at 6:00pm.<n><n>### Response   :  Jackie asked her husband Jack if she could go and see the movie on Friday. As it was Friday it was Jack’s weekend to be at leisure. He asked for 6 tickers for the movie on Friday evening and said that if he had time he would come to go and see the movie as well. His business trip was between 10:0am that morning until Friday at 5pm even though he had Friday after work as well to go and see the film.<n><n>### <n>

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could you add a line to? Choices:  A: bus stop B: graph C: post office D: grass E: play<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input.Scoring <n><n>**Question**: How many lines would be added by an instruction that says, In a classroom.<n><n>#### Type 1. If/Then <n><n>There may be 1 Type 1: The number of lines that will be added by an instruction such as these is the 1:If, where there is 1:then.<n><n>#### Type2. What? <n><n>There may 3 Type 2: The number of lines added by an instruction that includes “what” is the 0.2 if “what”, and it is the remaining the number of lines if “what” is excluded.<n><n>

This rhetorical question leads the reader to think about the answers they believe are correct and it also allows them to justify their reasoning which can allow them to make a logical response.<n><n>### Input A: When you count by 10s, how many whole numbers are there?<n><n>### Response A:<n><n>> **When it reaches zero you must stop counting**<n>><n>> With the response, A is able to answer the prompt effectively. <n><n>### Input B: When you count by one, how many whole numbers can you count?<n><n>### B Is the correct response:<n><n>> **The prompt needs the input of B**<n>><n>> When you count by one you can account a whole numbers and a fraction (1.0) <n><n>### In the case of the following multiple choice statement, if it were true that both A and B were false, would it support the conclusion that the conclusion is likely correct?<n><n>### If A, then it means B is incorrect. If B then A is probably incorrect. If A implies B then B implies A. If B implies A, then A implies B.<n><n>B. If A implies B, then B implies A.<n><n>> Given the above scenario, A implies B, thus, B also implies A.<n><n>### Write the hypothesis you wish to test.<n><n>`This is the hypothesis:`  This is the hypothesis:<n><n>`Statement of Hypothesis:`: `The hypothesis is this statement:`<n><n>`Predictions:` :`If my hypothesis is true, what predictions would you expect?`<n><n>### Write alternative hypotheses.<n><n>`There isn't alternative hypotheses`<n><n>### Develop or obtain the operational definitions of the variables.<n><n>`Vocabulary:` To obtain the operational definitions for the variables we use the vocabulary<n><n>`If your hypothesis is true?:` When it relates to the concept?<n><n>### List the independent and dependent variables.<n><n>`Independent Variable:`<n><n>``Dependent Variable(s):`<n><n>### Choose the type of experimental design.<n><n>`An experiment must have independent variable

How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n><n>### Response:		You should do all of them in response to the situation<n><n>### InputHow many hours have you spent on this quiz?<n><n>### Demons:<n>* How many hours have you spent studying Math?<n><n>### Input  How much did you study for the last test?<n><n>### Solution:<n>If you want to finish in 10 hours, you will have to finish it 4 hours before you've finish 2/3 of the book<n><n>### Input<n>How many yards does your pants have?<n>My pants have 33 yards.<n><n>### Output<n>Your pants have 10 yards less than 87 yards<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>### Include<n>[Link to quiz](https://www.wattpad.com/844639584-math-210-quiz-39-24-question-110-2017-07-28)<n><n>### Output link<n>[Link to video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uCxvfQz8Hj4)

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Write 3 + 2 + 5 = 10<n><n>5. Write 5 x 7 = 35<n><n>6. Write 2.5 x 6 = 15<n>#####<n><n>1. Write 120 - 85 = 35<n>2. Write 12 – 1.5 = 10.5<n>3. Write 5 –.75 = 4.25<n>4. Write 5 x.85 = 4.3<n>5. Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		mississippi<n><n>## Input:<n>> 3. 50% of the class is female. 10% of the class owns a dog. 80% of the dog owners play a musical instrument. If 7.5% of the class own dogs, what is the class average number of musicians?<n>>

(67)".<n><n><n>### Demands:<n>1. Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda.<n>2. She has 4 times as many cards as Mara.<n>3. Your response should explain how to manipulate the expression to solve for a particular letter.<n><n>### Example:  <n><n>### Instuction: The expression _x_ -_y_ + _y_ equals _x - 2y_. If _x_ = 5 and _y_ = 5, what is the value of _a_?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Instutor's Note: A letter or number could be replaced with a subscript to make clear its order of precedence.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Let's say I was making a pie. Now a pie has exactly 100 pieces of any sort, and I give 5 of them out. What's remaining?<n><n>### A. Eighty-five<n><n>### Response. Eighty-three<n><n>### My response: My response:<n><n>### Demo A. 65 pieces of whatever you were making. Demo B. One hundred and eighty-three, Eighty-three. My answer: 100 pieces. <n>

Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		A: go to jail<n><n>### Explanation: The man was guilty and a judge condemns the man based on his passing sentence.<n><n>#### Other choice:<n>E: judgement<n>Judgement is a different topic.<n><n>#### Reason:<n><n>1) Judgement does not relate to the task at hand.<n><n>2) Judgement is used in a different context.<n><n>Input:What would we do if we had infinite wishes? Choices:  If I had 2 wishes, they would only lead to more wishes. If I had an infinite wishes I would be able to do a lot of things. I would wish wealth as 90% of the time you will have it. I would wish for more wishes because in an infinite time you can be sure you will never run out. As soon as you get wealth, you can then start making your wishes come true. We could have a super good time once we realize it's all worthless but this is not allowed when you are a kid.<n><n>### Response:[If I had 2 wishes,] they would only lead to [more wishes.]<n><n>### Examplification:<n><n><n>There were a lot of wishes but they didn't do anything to change the world. Since this is a limited world, I wished for more wishes. That was the only effect of it.<n><n><n>Thinking about wealth, you would want to be wealthy, you could finally get your favorite ice cream. The first wish would make me happy but the second wish would make me want more things.<n><n>There are too many options. You would either use a wish for money to increase productivity or increase enjoyment.<n><n><n>### Other choice:<n><n>3) If I had an infinite number of wishes, I would have infinite wishes so I could wish for infinite wishes so I could change everything about the world. I would do whatever I wanted with them because all people are equal and I could choose what to do with any wish I had a lot. After wishing for money, this would make me want to have infinite wishes because I would not want to be poor for the rest of my life. Next, I would not think too much about it because I would only be thinking about how I could spend these wishes on stuff that doesn’t matter anymore because you are rich. I would never say “why don’t I wish for more

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where could you put a dollar that would make it hard to get out without breaking? Choices:  A: cash drawer B: piggy bank C: purse D: box E: pocket<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A or B<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:There's a lot to reproducing, but it begins and end with new life by giving what? Choices:  A: overpopulation B: birth C: presents D: propagation E: fun<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Answer:<n>###<n>

Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>Sleep helps our memory.  A restful sleep can give our brain the chance to make connections between the activities we do during the day. Sleeping also allows your mind to form new information that you learned during that day.<n><n><n>### Response<n>A<n><n>When I am sleepy, I usually do a few of the below things.<n><n>1. I take a nap<n>2. I take a shower<n>3. I drink coffee<n>4. I get in some exercising<n><n>### Inputs:Choices:  A: take a nap B: shower C: Exercise<n><n>### Response

After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What will you need to do to decide whether to be seeing artifacts? Choices:  A: learning B: painful memories C: thinking D: awe inspiring E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		E

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: study philosophy B: become adult C: ask questions D: further education E: study together<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A: become adult B: study philosophy C: further education D: ask questions E: study together<n>Input:In every school year, school begins in September. School lasts until early May. During school, students study different subjects and take tests to prove they understand each subject. Teachers grade the tests, then they report the results, which are called grades. Grades are reported to a student’s parents at the end of the year. Grade levels are described with numbers. 4–6 is elementary school, 7–12 is middle and high school, and 13–18 is college. 7=P+G/4, which equals 7, because in grade school, children get 4 points for their grades, and their grade is P+G/4 (P=points, G=grade). 8=P*(6/5), which equals 8, because in grade 8, children get 1 more point for their grades, than grade 7. 9=2+P+(13/4*G+13/4/G), which equals 11, because in grade 9, children get 13 more points for their grades (P=points, 13=grade, 4=number of grades, 11=sum of points, which equals the grades of the number of grade). 10=P*(G+5/8), which equals 13, because in grade 10 they get 13 more grades than in grade nine. 11=P*(10/9), which equals 14, because students get their lowest grade in middle school, and they get high grades in high school. 12=2+P+(G*11/G), which equals PG as the number of grades, which equals the grands of points. 13=2+P+(24/9*G), which equals 27, because in the twelfth grade, students are awarded more points than their seventh-grade grades (P+24=9/2, 24=grade, 9=the number of grade, 27=the 13th grade, which equals 27 points, which equals the number points). 14=2+P5/3, because the fifth grade equals

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If the description is underground, it is not high. To describe how tall a building is, we can simply say how many floors it has, not how many inches it is off the ground. Therefore, if the Empire State building is tall by itself, it is not small.<n><n>If it were underground, it would be called an underground building, or a basement. If it were high, it would be called a skyscraper.<n><n>Since the Empire State building is not underground, and it is not tiny, tall is the only word that describes it.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Why would you not want to be working with wood? Choices:  A: blisters B: frustration C: being paid D: make money E: money<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demian:<n><n>### Input<n>Demonstration:<n>How many gallons would be needed to fill 2 bathtubs that hold 1/6 as much? Answer: 6<n>Input: Pete rode his bike 5 miles uphill and 8 miles downhill. Later, while riding to work, he traveled 7 miles with the wind at his back and 5 miles into a stiff headwind. How far did he ride altogether?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### How many gallons would be required to fill 2 batheaus that are half as large as the other one?<n><n>### Which two units of measure describe a person's height? Children learn many things through reading<n><n>### Choic<n>D<n><n>## Instrucition:Read the text to choose the correct answer. Choose one response that correctly responds to the request. A dog is usually the best way to keep a family safe, but not an aggressive type of dog. The most aggressive dogs should not be kept as pets, because they may seriously injure or even kill a smaller animal or person. An aggressive dog should, by law, be put to sleep. This is particularly important in an urban situation where people, even children, are likely to be approached by or walk near dogs off-leash. A dog bite by an unknown dog is unprovoked and unpredictable and in this situation the dog

When solving inequalities. you can multiply or divide the variable by a value greater than or equal to 1 but not greater than 10 and not a fraction.<n>2.   The product of a positive number multiplied by any number is positive.<n>3.   The product of two negative numbers is always a negative number.<n>4.   The product of one positive and one negative number is always positive.<n>5.   The sum of two negative numbers is a negative number.<n>6.   The sum of a negative and a positive number is zero.<n>7.   The sum of -5 3 is -4.<n>8.   The sum of one positive and one positive number can be positive and negative.<n>9.   The sum of the two  is 6.<n>10. -60 + 60 = -40<n>11.-27 6<n>12. -4(X5<n>13. 4*3 = 12<n>14. 9*(13/5) = 981<n>15. 3*(12 + 7) = 40<n>16. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What is likely to happen to someone's speech after becoming inebriated? Choices:  A: regret B: automobile accidents C: drunk driving D: talking nonsense E: talk intelligently<n><n>### Response:		<n>A

Write a program that takes a string of words (e.g. "the quick brown fox") and gives the number of times each consecutive letter appears, i.e. the string "the quick brown" yields 3 "s" appearances, 1 each for "e", "r", "t", "b", "q", "u", "f", "x".  The "e" and "m" don't appear, you count their occurrence in the original string, not the ones that are found in "quick", "fox", etc.<n><n>Sample output: [the quick brown fox] yields [s: 3, e: 0, r: 1, t: 1, b: 1, q: 1, u: 1, f: 1, x: 1, p: 0];  [the quick rude] is the input;  [s: 3] is your output.<n><n>### Input<n><n>First line contains the string the quick brown fox<n>Output the number of times that each consecutive letter appears<n><n>##### <n><n>### 3.<n>Write a program to find an 5 letter word in a given sentence by using the wordlist.<n>Sample input & output:<n><n>given "There was a man eating cake. It was the best cake he had ever tasted."  your wordlist is "man eat cake"<n>so, the output of 5 letter long word would be "eat" because the given input is exactly the same with the wordlist.<n><n>### 4.<n>Given a list of numbers, print the odd-digit numbers and the even-digit numbers.<n>sample:<n>the list is "31, 6, 80, 123"<n>the output should be "1, 3, 6" & "8, 0, 12"<n><n>### Solution:<n>Write a for loop and print a string as the user input.<n>repeat it 2 times.<n><n>

Some people think that the museum is free on weekends, but in fact, it is $30 per weekend day. Other people believe that there is no museum at all in New York City.<n>Answer: closed:<n><n>### Discussion:<n><n>### Examples:<n>Input: At the park, there is a carousel. Some people think that there is a zoo at the park, but in fact, there is no zoo at the park.<n>Answer: zoo<n><n>Input: Some people think that a school bus is yellow, but in fact, school buses come in various colors.<n>Answer: Yellow<n><n>Input: Some believe that elephants are endangered, but in fact, they’re not.<n>Answer: Endangered<n><n>Input: Some think they have a chance of winning, but in fact, their chances are 64/1 instead or 1/64.<n>Answer: Win<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Write your request, such as, “What are open 7 days a week.”<n><n>### Input/explanation:<n><n>### Input example 1: “What do you think?” or “What information provided?”<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### What’s included in/excluded from the list that we can think of?<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>### Response 1:<n>### Solution 1:<n>## Demand: What is the list?<n>## Demand example: Open 7 days a week<n>## Answer: Closed<n><n>## Instrucciones:Answer the multiple choice question.<n>## Demoniation/instructions:Research your answer<n><n>## Evaluate your response by clicking the “Request” and/or the “I Agree” on the bottom left of the demo and then click “Go back.”<n>

Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>B.A monkey is found in the rainforests<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Given the sentence: 5 is 30 more than 6<n>You will solve the riddle below.<n><n>### Riddle:A man gives 1/5 of a certain amount to everyday and receives 1/7 as much at the end of each day. If in 30 days he has received $10 more than he had at the beginning and has received $2.50 each day, what does he have at the end of 30 days?<n><n>### Answer:If the man receives $2.50 every day, then he is getting $225 at the end of 40 days ($225 is 1/7 less of $250).<n><n>The man has $250 at the end of 20 days. He receives $2.5/1(1/20) = $1.25 more each day to get to $250. So he has $1.25 + $2.5 = $3.75 more at the end of 19 days.<n><n>So he has $250 + $3.75 + $3.74 + 1.25 + 1.2225 + $3.6925 + $36.92 = $283.87 dollars in 20 days.<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>1.The 5 is 36 more than 7<n><n>2.Five is 25% more than 7.<n><n>### ANSWER:<n>A.The answer is d.<n><n>### INPUT:<n><n>Write an alphabetical series. It is alphabetical because you have to go through the alphabet.<n><n>### EXAMPLE:<n><n>### OUTPUT:<n><n>A series of alphabeticals can be created by moving up one letter at a time.<n>```<n>B,C,D,E,F<n>```<n><n>### INSTRUCTIONS:<n><n>In the problem: 11 minus 5, answer the following question.<n><n>## Example<n><n>## Question<n><n>How many 3 digit numbers can you add together to get 65?<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>5

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Trouser leg<n><n>### Input<n>Write a statement or two that makes the ferret in your choice of location likely to be found. <n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a statement that completes the request. <n><n>## Instructions<n>Give the correct answer to the question above.<n><n>## Input <n>The correct answer is:<n><n>### The correct answer is: <n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### If you answered:<n>```<n>    A:  cupboard <n>    B: countertop <n>    C: water D:  hardware department E: english<n>```<n>You're correct!<n><n>In other words **A** is **1**, and **C** is **2**.<n><n>### If not, here is your opportunity to try again!<n><n>### HINT:<n>```<n>How do you figure the answer?<n>```<n><n>Here's an example in action.<n><n>### In the example below<n><n>**Input:(Janet has 9 cards)**<n><n>**Input:(Mara has twice as many cards)**<n><n>### What is the answer?<n>```	<n>How much do they have in all?<n>```<n><n>> How do you calculate the answer?<n><n>### Demonicating the 3 step process<n>![](step-1.png)<n><n>> Here's where you go into detail!<n><n>### Step 1:<n><n>Input: How many lessons did Jocelynn have this week?<n><n>Answer:<n>10 lessons<n><n>> How do we calculate that answer?<n><n>## Step 2:<n><n>Input: Jocelynn needs to drive her bus home, and takes the route home as below<n>5 blocks from her house to the bus garaje in Houston<n>20 blocks to the Post office to pick up some stamps<n>2 blocks back and forth from the post office to pick up the stamps<n>5 blocks back and forth from her bus to her car<n><n>> Which route takes less time? (the first one)<n>10 lessons						15 lessons<n><n>	<n>## Step 3:<n>* Add those up and get the final answer! <n><n><n>### Conclusion!<n><n>To be a successful data miner, you'll need to know **how to get to the right answers quickly, and understand the data from the beginning to the ending.**<n><n>The best way to master something, is learn it from the beginning, practice it until you're able to do it without conscious effort, then apply it at the end.<n><n>You've just found out where to keep a teakettles, as well as a great new learning method for **Data Mining**.<n><n>Enjoy

Which value is closest to the number of gallons that you can fill from these cups? He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:We were having a canned food drive and I needed to pick up some contributions, where did I go? Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		Because it is a ______, it was not stored in the refrigerator but in ______ because it is ______.<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately identifies the choice that was made.<n><n>### Requirements:<n><n>-   The response should not provide the correct choice.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:We were having a food drive and I needed canned goods. Where did I go? Choice: A - Shelf<n><n>Input: A: cellar<n><n>Input: B: cupboard<n><n>Input: C: refrigeration<n><n>Input: D: Grocery store<n><n>Response:D: cupboard because it was stored in the refridgerator because food spoiled if not properly stored.<n><n>### Input.<n>Jasmine, Chelsea, and Kelsey go to the park every Sunday. If Jasmine walks 5 miles to the park and walks 5 miles back to home, how far does Chelsea walk to the park and how far does she walk on the way back?<n><n>Response: Kelsey: 10 miles, Jasmine: 15 miles<n><n>### Instctions.<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Response.<n>Answer:Chelsea and Kelsey walk twice as far as Jasmine.Jasmine walks 20 miles.<n><n>### Note.<n>You are not permitted to use a calculator.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Jasmine had the shortest amount of time.<n><n>### Solution.<n><n>Input:Chelsea has to go to Sally's house five houses from her own. She walks 5 houses and turns around and walks 10 houses. How far is Sally's house from her own house? Answer: 30 house<n><n>### Problem.<n>If Sam has 5 times as many dollars as Susan, how many dollars will Sam have if he has 3 less than the number of dollars Susan has?<n><n>### Answer.<n>A: 27<n><n>### Notes.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>If you divide 25 by 4 you get 6. If you divide 250 by 4 you get ______.<n><n>Output: 62.5
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The wheel was loose, and threatened to fall off when they were what? i < input.Length; i++)<n>                {<n>                    if (input[i] >= 'A' && input[i] <= 'H')<n>                    {<n>                        questionInputs[i] = int.Parse(input[i].ToString());<n>                    }<n><n>                }<n>                //Find how many choices there are for example if the input is <n>                //22233:A, B, then that means there are 3 different letters<n>                //that the user might want to answer with A B C<n>                if (input.Length > MultipleChoiceInput.Length - 1)<n>                {<n>                    <n>                    multipleChoiceInput = input;<n>                    multipleChoiceAnswer = "<!";<n>                    Console.WriteLine(multipleChoiceAnswer);<n>                    Console.Write(inputAnswers);<n>                    continue;<n>                }<n>                else if (input.Length <= MultipleChoiceInput.Length && input.Length >= MultipleChoiceInput.Length)<n>                {<n><n>                    for (int i = MultipleChoiceInput.Length; i < input.ToUpper().ToCharArray().Length; i++)

In English, requests can take the form of a question, or a statement (which implies that the reader/listener should understand that they might need to complete the task).  <n>    In this case, the student is being given the task of analyzing a question, and the student is then requested (via response) to fill in the blank.

Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		Choices that would be considered a poor answer; Parents often yell in time of chaos to try to vent their anger.<n><n>### What to do; Consider the choices as correct/incorrect and not the whole input as wrong.<n><n>### How it works; The input will be divided with the number of options given in the instructions.<n><n>### Examples; You will receive a set of options, divide the options into as many pieces as there is in the instructions, and then chose one option for each division.<n><n>### Question: <n><n>Your response will make sure to check out the question to make sure you are giving the right answer and it also makes sure to answer the question correctly. You will not get this wrong because you must make it so you can see if you are answering them correctly.<n><n>### Inputs and outputs; The instruction will give you inputs which will have a number that will equal the number of options that they give in the instructions. Therefore, you will give a piece for each of those options. The output is an actual question, therefore, you will only be given two options to choose from.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:What could there be in a beauty salon? How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:The woman experienced great joy, but despite that this was a what? Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		My heifer is a female cattle, so we need to pick the place where the cow/heifer goes to milk the cow to produce milk milk and also to produce a calf, like when the girl has a baby.<n>When we put the heifer and my girl, they will make a big happy marriage to produce cute heifer calves and maybe bulls too (calves is pronounced as kalves). In dairy farm, they produce and sell milk/dairy produce.<n>On the Dairy Farm, there is a cow with 5 calves, and there are 2 more bulls.<n>In Farm Field, they grow crops for the animals to eat.<n>There is a dog farm in the East.<n>In a county fair, we have a lot of fun with the animals.<n><n>### Input:'Five' times 'ninety-six' is what?' Choices:  A. 480  B. 48 T. 4800 C. 48 T D. 24<n><n>### Response:'five' is pronounced as fife, which is same as the musical instrument fi.<n><n>### What is an integer?<n>- An integer is a positive or a negative whole number.<n><n>### A place value chart for ones shows how many ones make a whole.<n>- Place value chart is a list which classifies one column of numbers to another column.<n><n>### There are two ways to add whole numbers.<n>- An example is:<n>- $10 + 12 = $22 \text and }<n>24<n><n>## Evaluate if an answer is reasonable<n><n>### Example:<n>If a girl rides her bike twice as fast as her dog goes, she will get to her brother's house in 1 1/3 hours more than the dog takes to get there.<n><n>### Example Solution:<n>If a dog walks at a speed of $1$. Then, to get to my brother's house, the girl travels at $2$ and the total time is $2$ hours. But the answer said $1 1/3$ hour, so it must be $1 + 2/3 = 1.666 = 1.6$.<n><n>### Example Evaluation:<n>Based on the example above, one

If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? "I don't like eating at home." is more polite than "I don't eat at home." B. "I don' t like to eat at home." is more formal than "I don' t eat at home." C. "I don'y like to eat at home is similar to "I don't eating at home." D. "I don' like eating at home" is informal. E. "I don' eat at home is not formal.<n><n>### Response 1:D<n><n>### Input2: Which statement is more polite than the other? A. "I need to study English." B. "I have to study English." C.
